continued to support us, and to our tenants in Haddington House.ldquoThese incomes enable us to offer all the buildings at the Poldrate free, to the community and for the community.Although the Bridge Centre has been closed, the staff have not been idle.Online youth classes and music lessons have been taking place, while the community outreach team, along with the community wardens and police, have been out every weekend since June last year.Christmas and Easter appeals have been organised, while the Lammermuir Larder, which provides a local community food initiative set up to support people struggling financially, was established in February.The closure has also given the opportunity to see ldquomuch-needed maintenance carried out in the building.

title: dunbar-schoolboy-parts-foot-hair-good-cause
story: Ansel Parkin has already unicycled and run his way to raising hundreds of pounds for East Lothian Foodbank and Comic Relief.Now, the Dunbar Primary School pupil has said goodbye to his long locks to boost the Little Princess Trust.Proud mum Kirsty told the Courier: ldquoHe is loving his new hair.ldquoSometimes he says that he misses his long hair but he really enjoys his new hair.ldquoHe has noticed his hair is growing exceptionally fast!The -year-old had been growing his hair for about two years ldquomostly because he could not decide on a haircut.His mum said that the youngster wanted to have it cut while in primary seven and also to mark the end of lockdown.On April , he made the trip to Jack and Ivy on Dunbar High Street for the change of style.Neighbour Aimee Muirhead was given the honour of chopping the Dunbar youngsterrsquos locks, which have been sent off to the Little Princess Trust.The charity provides real-hair wigs for youngsters who have lost their hair through cancer or due to other illnesses.A minimum of seven inches of hair is needed to make a wig, with donors urged to raise money and send their hair to the good cause.Kirsty, who lives in Dunbar with husband Dan and Anselrsquos brother Ebon, , said: ldquoAnselrsquos hair had become so long that it was actually at the end of lockdown that it seemed as good a time as any to mark it and do some fundraising.ldquoYou have to donate over six inches and his hair was probably I think about  centimetreslong and he had about  centimetrescut off.Ansel, who last spring unicycled  miles for East Lothian Foodbank alongside his brother, also raised more than pound through an online fundraising page.Then, earlier this year, he swapped one wheel for lacing up his running shoes in aid of Comic Relief.He was joined by classmate Jake Page in running a mile every hour for  hours.Jake was dressed as superhero lsquoThe Flashrsquo, while Ansel donned a pair of butterfly wings for the occasion.To support Ansel, go to uk.virginmoneygiving KirstyParkin

title: ross-high-rugby-club-delighted-newly-refurbished-gym
story: Found in the club on Blawearie Road, the new facility is currently open to adult players, who can take part in activities in line with the current coronavirus regulations and those set out by the Scottish Rugby Union.It is also hoped that, in future, youngsters from the townrsquos Recharge facility could have access to the gym.Ross Highrsquos players have not been able to fully train for seven months due to Covid rules, with restricted training taking place since April.Players have only now been able to resume regular training, the first time since November.Called the Chris Miller Fitness Suite after the clubrsquos long-time player and the projectrsquos major sponsor, the gym contains several weight benches, racks, weights, a bike machine, and two other weight machines.There is also a personal best board for players to mark and record their performance.A dumbbell rack will be the last piece of equipment installed, still to be purchased by the club.Almost all of the equipment was brand new, with the old second-hand pieces that used to be in place now no longer fit for purpose and not suitable for rugby.The gym, found near the changing facilities, is decorated in the clubrsquos colours.Work took place over seven months. The old gym was stripped bare, the walls painted, a new ventilation and sound system installed and new flooring put in.The club raised more than pound, in sponsorship from members, players, coaches and sponsors to help make the project a reality, while the Walk With Scott Foundation ndash whose founder, the late Scott Glynn, was the clubrsquos former president ndash and East Lothian Council also helped bring the gym to le.Due to Covid restrictions, players have to book a slot beforehand.Ryan Strachan, Ross Highrsquos rugby and business officer, said that with the season the club had had, the new gym was some good news.He added: ldquoA huge amount of work has gone into this project from initial fundraising, socially distanced work from a small group of volunteers and now organising safe re-opening for players using an online booking system.ldquoOn behalf of the club, a big thanks to our sponsors, contributors, the small group of highly committed volunteers and our suppliers.ldquoIf it wasnrsquot for membership and people wanting to help, we wouldnrsquot be able to do a lot of things.Younger players will be able to access the gym in due course in cooperation with Active Schools, while those who attend the townrsquos Recharge could also soon be able to use it.

title: new-colouring-book-east-lothian-reveals-rich-history
story: A History of East Lothian Colouring Book is a heartfelt tribute to the unique heritage of the county.The illustrations ndash based on the history of East Lothian ndash include the Roman Temple of Mithras at Musselburgh, the Siege of Haddington and detailed images of Scottish coastal industries.The book is being sold to raise funds for the Waggonway Project, which runs a heritage centre in Cockenzie celebrating the history of Scotlandrsquos first railway.Cockenziersquos Alan Braby, a founding member of the group and illustrator of the book, spoke about his new publication.He told the Courier: ldquoAs an archaeological illustrator living in East Lothian, the history, archaeology and local scenery is outstanding.ldquoIn my reconstruction drawings, I have always tried to include it all, from early prehistory to the unknown, but I have recently rediscovered events and incidents of the th and th centuries.ldquoFrom a large portfolio of images, we were able to select a few that gave a potted history of East Lothian that proved most suitable to this publication.The Waggonway Project was set up to protect and publicise the route of Scotlandrsquos first railway, the  Tranent-Cockenzie Waggonway.Ed Bethune, Waggonway Project chairman, was delight with the bookrsquos launch.He said: ldquoAlanrsquos work has been a big part of the success of the Waggonway Project since  and we are delighted to celebrate this by bringing his fantastic artwork to a wider audience of all ages.ldquoThe book is greatyou want to add colour, or evenyou just want a collection of superb archaeological reconstruction to admire, and we are very grateful to Alan for his generosity in donating the proceeds to our community heritage projects.Alanrsquos book is available for purchase on the Waggonway website: waggonway product-page alan-braby-s-east-lothian-colouring-book

title: refurbishment-alterations-planned-cockenzie-primary-school
story: East Lothian Council is seeking permission to make alterations, including the demolition of a redundant chimney, at Cockenzie Primary School.The planning application, which is being considered by the local authorityrsquos planning department, outlines the work proposed.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council anticipated that the work could be carried out during the school holidays.She said: ldquoSubject to planning approval, work will be carried out at Cockenzie Primary School over the summer holidays involving major external refurbishment.ldquoThis includes flat roofing works, rooflight and window replacement, installation of an external insulated render system and the demolition of a redundant chimney.ldquoIn addition, internal works include an electrical rewire, new lighting and suspended ceilings to be undertaken to five classrooms.ldquoThis is part of a rolling programme of primary school project works and maintenance.

title: new-owners-taking-drummohr-caravan-park
story: International real estate advisor Savills, on behalf of private clients, has completed the sale of Drummohr at Levenhall, Musselburgh, to employee-owned leisure, retail and distribution specialist WCF Ltd for an undisclosed amount.Jo Ritzema, managing director of WCF Ltd, said this was the companyrsquos first caravan, camping and glamping site in Scotland, with the nearest being a five-star facility at Herding Hill Farm near Hadrianrsquos Wall in Northumberland.She stressed that the company hoped to go on to increase its portfolio of camping and glamping sites in southern Scotland and the north of England.The site is developed to accommodate  luxury holiday letting lodges, seven of which have hot tubs,  touring caravans, tents and motorhomes, together with  glamping units.The site also includes a storage area for up to  touring caravans, a three-bedroom bungalow with hot tub, two amenity blocks and a shop.The .-acresite is situated in the formerly walled gardens of a monastery and was converted to a holiday park in . It has been owned and run by the same family since .Mrs Ritzema first visited Drummohr as a camper herself, saying it benefited from the draw of Edinburgh and the ldquobeautul coastline and countryside of East Lothian.She said that the company, which has its registered office at Brampton, near Carlisle, had started an external refurbishment programme at Drummohr involving painting and decorating, with further plans to ldquoupdate and upgrade the facilities such as lodges and glamping units.She said that the site had a large touring area for tents and caravans which would also be improved, with the amenity blocks, accommodating showers, toilets and laundry, refurbished. It was also planned to add an indoor area including a kitchen for campers.Mrs Ritzema added that, given the ldquosignicant growth in glamping, additional units would be provided subject to consultation and the necessary planning consents.She added that the seven staff members, one of them part-time, who worked at the site had been retained, with a recruitment process under way for a further three or four new employees.They either live on-site or in the local area, including Angie Purves, an East Lothian resident who has been promoted from office manager to take over the running of Drummohr.Mrs Ritzema said that everyone involved in the venture was ldquomadly excited by it all and added that a new website for the site would highlight local visitor attractions.Richard Prestwich, director in the leisure and trade team at Savills, said: ldquoHoliday parks have become exceptionally sought-after due to the growing trend for staycations. It is encouraging to witness new entrants, such as WCF, targeting the holiday parks market and competing with the existing multi-park owners that have traditionally dominated the marketplace.

title: josh-taylors-fiancee-danielle-murphy-ecstatic-win---hoping-start-wedding-planning
story: Danielle Murphy watched the fight from home in Haddington after Covid- restrictions prevented her from flying to Las Vegas.Josh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed world championDanielle told the Courier: ldquoI am absolutely ecstatic about his win, he has made history."All the hard work, dedication and years that he has put into his craft have paid off.ldquoI was gutted not to fly over, there have been other times when he has gone away and we havenrsquot been able to be there but with the magnitude of this fight, everyone wanted to be there to support him, but we were all cheering him on and screaming for him at the television.Danielle said the Taylor family are excited to celebrate when the world champion touches down in Scotland today , but Covid- restrictions are making it dficult.She said: ldquoWe are having to play it by ear because it is hard to book anything."Normally we would go into a hall or celebrate in a pub but there are only so many people you can have in aand there is no way you could only pick  people to celebrate, so we arenrsquot doing that.ldquoWe are hoping to be able to get an open-top bus for him, but we need to seethe council will allow that.Danielle was disappointed by the lack of national televised coverage of the fight.She said: ldquoIt is absolutely shocking that the fight wasnrsquot broadcast on a bigger  for others to be able to watch.ldquoThe older generation do not have smartphones, so they were struggling to watch it when it was on because it was streamed through an app."Danielle said Josh was flying home on Tuesday for some well-deserved time off.The couple got engaged in Dubai last December.Danielle said: "Hopefully he can take some time off so we can get our wedding planned and chill for a while."

title: picture-gallery-duke-duchess-cambridge-visit-heavy-sound-cockenzie
story: William and Catherine, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, were in Cockenzie yesterday as part of their ongoing tour of Scotland.The couple were visiting Heavy Sound, which works with the Scottish Violence Reduction Unit , a joint project backed by the police and the Scottish Government which tries to tackle the root causes of violence.During the visit, the Duke and Duchess saw young people doing martial arts, music production and bicycle maintenance, organised by community organisation Heavy Sound, which is based at the Cockenzie Hub on Edinburgh Road.Manager Thilo Pfander persuaded Kate to try her hand at making some EDMand at first the Duchess received some encouragement from her husband, who said: "Yeah, drop a beat in the background."Kate did produce a bass-heavy track but added a piercing synth sound over the top.William laughed and said: "Whats that "It sounded like a cat... It might catch on ndash in about a hundred years time!"After a few moments, William pleaded for it to stop,saying: "Its hurting my ears."He then added: "Im not sure its number one material yet."

title: spectators-welcomed-musselburgh-racecourse-afternoon
story: The East Lothian track will admit  pre-booked race spectators at noon todayin the first step towards resuming normal racing.The racecourse worked carefully with East Lothian Councils Safety Advisory Group to establish a raceday protocol ahead of the event.Alcohol and food can only be ordered but must be consumed at tables in a designated picnic area, while a two-metre distancing rule will be enforced throughout the course.Musselburgh Racecourse said in a post on Facebook today: ldquoThe track is in great condition today. Were thrilled to welcome back spectators for the first time since February !The sold-out event will host eight races, with the first beginning at .pm.The next spectator event at the Musselburgh track is The Edinburgh Cup Raceday on Saturday, June .Musselburghs popular Stobo Castle Ladies Day has been moved from August  to August  to give spectators the best chance of relaxed Covid- rules.For a full fixture list and to book tickets, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: heros-welcome-josh-taylor-boxer-arrives-home-prestonpans
story: Proud residents gathered outside the Prestoungrange Gothenburg to welcome home their own Tartan Tornado after he beat his American rival Jose Ramirez in Las Vegas this weekend.Josh was crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the world on Saturday after a stunning unanimous points victory.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the worldDedicated fans braved the cold and rain to catch a glimpse of the world champion as he arrived home.Josh, accompanied by his fianceacutee Danielle Murphy, slowed his car to soak in the adulation of the crowd that had gathered outside his local pub.One of the first to greet the heroic boxer was his dad, James .Diane Taylor, Joshs mum, said she was overwhelmed seeing her son again as he ed home from his history-making win.She added: "I feel absolutely amazing."The energy of him driving through was amazing because I was panicking there wasnt going to be anybody here because of a mix-up with the flights and everything, but when I saw everybody I was so pleased, it is brilliant."The crowd erupted into cheers and chants as the champion drove down High Street at pm.Lara Connerton and Kenny Ainslie came out to celebrate Joshs arrivalOne resident, Lara Connerton, said: "I am super proud, it is absolutely amazing."He stopped and spoke to everyone and he took photos with the children in the streets."He is absolutely lovely, a top guy.""We are going to go and have a pint to celebrate."Another, Kenny Ainslie, said: "Its lovely seeing him, we are so proud."The Courier was live from Prestonpans when Josh arrived ndash watch a short video of his arrival here.

title: heading
story: Carrie Williamson was with her son and daughter, Finlay and Bonnie Loftus, aged seven and five, and their bulldog Mable, when they saw the stone propped up against a fence by Prestoungrange Mining Museum, Prestonpans.Read More: Heros welcome for Josh Taylor as he arrives home in PrestonpansJosh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival Jose Ramirez with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion in Las Vegas on Saturday."The children were super excited to find it especially when they realised it was specially made for a world champion," said Carrie.The family, who live at Pinkie Braes, took a quick photo of the stone and put it back in its place for others to find and enjoy.Read More: Josh Taylors fiancee excited to plan wedding to the heroJosh, who ed to Scotland yesterday, was greeted with a herorsquos welcome as he passed through Prestonpans at pm.Supporters gathered outside the Prestongrange Gothenburg to cheer for the titleholder as he slowed his car to soak in the elated crowds.Read More: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed champion of the worldFans waved Scottish flags and signs on the High Street as Josh headed home to Haddington for some well-deserved rest.One sign read: lsquoHaud yir wheest Ramiz, your belts are coming tae the Pans.rsquoResidents from Northbank Road, Prestonpans, huddled together amid the cold on Saturday night to watch Joshrsquos fight on a projector.A banner on the street said: ldquoThis is my hometown, the place I was born in, no matter where I go itrsquos in my soul.ldquoMy feet may wander a thousand places, but my heart will lead me back home to Prestonpans.

title: lone-swan-finds-new-love-river-esk-musselburgh
story: Bonnie was taken to a new home on the River Esk when she abandoned her nest at Figgate Park, Portobello, after losing her partner Clyde.It appeared he had been in a fight with another male swanand had to be put to sleep.Sarah Auldsmith, Scottish SPCA senior animal rescue officer, said: ldquoWe were contacted back in April about an injured swan at Figgate Park.ldquoIt appeared a resident male swan, Clyde, had been in a fight with another male, resulting in a leg injury that made him unable to walk.ldquoClyde had also had bad arthritis for a number of years, which had been slowly getting worse.ldquoThis, coupled with him now being completely unable to stand, meant that he would not recover and the dficult decision was made to put him to sleep to end his suffering.She explained that Bonnie abandoned her nest about a month after losing Clyde.ldquoShe had been doing her best to incubate them but without her partner, and with her constantly being attacked by the new male, the eggs were unfortunately not viable, said Sarah.ldquoBonnie was moved to Musselburgh a couple of weeks ago and seems to be getting on well in her new environment.ldquoWe havenrsquot heardshersquos found a new mate yet but this is certainly a possibility as swans will often take up with another partner after their previous one has passed away.ldquoWhen she moved, Bonnie left her eggs in the nest and they have most likely been predated on since then.Photographer Angus Bathgate, from Wallyford, captured Bonnie on camera enjoying her new le on the Esk and it is thought she may have even have found love again, after being snapped with a new admirer.Mr Bathgate said that during a visit to the Esk, he was told by someone who was involved with the welfare of the swans that Bonnie could be singled out by the identication number on her tag.He added: ldquoIt made my day when Bonnie and her new mate chose to show their bonding together, which I captured on camera.Sarah appealed to the public: ldquoIf you discover any injured wildle, please contact our helpline on   .

title: heavy-sound-founder-says-dad-joke-duke-duchess-cambridge-bombed-visit
story: Jordan Butler met the royal couple at its premises in Cockenzie Business Hub as they learned about Heavy Soundrsquos work and its partnership with the Scottish Violence Reduction Unit .The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge during their visit. All images: Andy Buchanan PA WireArriving at .pm, the couple, known as the Earl and Countess of Strathearn when in Scotland, squeezed a lot into their hour-and--minute visit.Heavy Sound, which moved from Tranent to Cockenzie last July, was the only place the couple visited in the hub in what is thought to be their first official visit to East Lothian.The Duchess tried mixing a dance music track alongside Jordan and music services manager Thilo Pfander but received a scathing review from her husband.: Picture gallery of Duke and Duchess of Cambridge visiting Heavy Sound in CockenzieDespite her insisting the track be deleted, Jordan said it had been saved and was waiting to hear what he could do with it, joking of a pending release.He added that the track was not as bad as the Duke made out and he enjoyed listening to it.But his ldquodad joke to the duo of getting royalties from the song should it be released did not go down as well as he thought it would, he recalled.William and Catherine also visited Heavy Soundrsquos community reach and inclusion bus , which is kitted out with recording equipment, IT and office equipment, a kitchen and hairdressing space.Jordan said the royals took a great interest in the project, discussed how it came about and the work it does.He added: ldquoOn board the bus they had a big interest in mental health.ldquoThey also had in-depth knowledge of childhood trauma and work with early years it is obviously something they know about and have a lot of knowledge in.Heavy Sound partners with vulnerable, disadvantaged and disengaged young people using music and sport.About  per cent of the young people have care experience and or complex childhood trauma. It works with  young people and  adults.Heavy Sound is in partnership with the SVRU, which helped make the CRIB possible alongside support from the Scottish Prison Service and STV Childrenrsquos Appeal.During the pandemic, the CRIB became an lsquoalternative classroomrsquo, offering a safe place for the children of key workers and vulnerable children. It also distributed , lunches during the first lockdown and , in the second.The royal couple also watched the Thai boxing group and mixed martial arts programme lsquoFight Like A Girlrsquo."We tried our best to get them [the royal couple] involved in Thai boxing and hitting some of the pads but they were more interested in speaking to the young people, said Jordan.ldquoKate did go on the mat with her high heels on, which is a big no-no, but you can make exceptions for certain people!William declined the invitation, saying he did not have the right equipment but that he used to box during his time in the army.Heavy Sound also works on mentoring and building skills and development, with William and Catherine also visiting Heavy Soundrsquos bike maintenance facility.The visit meant a lot to Jordan, who was homeless himself from the age of  to  and suffered with substance misuse as a result. Music was how he expressed himself, which is one reason why Heavy Sound has such a focus on it and ldquobuilding relationships and more alternative and positive forms of expression.He added: ldquoWe are able to offer our young people as many opportunities for positive engagement as possible and show them that through building relationships and engaging, they can get opportunities.Jordan told the story of one girl who suffers from social anxiety ndash she not only made it through the door on the day of the visit but spoke to the royal couple and showed off her artwork in an experience that Jordan said ldquowill stay with her for the rest of her le.On the Duke and Duchess, he said: ldquoThey are lovely and really down to earth. I felt incredibly relaxed."But it was so surreal at the same time. It did become normal pretty quickly, though.

title: newhailes-house-musselburgh-reopens-brand-new-visitor-attractions
story: The Palladian Villa, which boasts original furnishings and possessions from more than  years of inhabitants, has reopened with brand new visitor attractions.The National Trust for Scotland property has undergone restoration work to welcome visitors again after a sprinkler system mal and a moth infestation saw it close in February .The conservation charity has introduced a brand new visitor experience inside the house, with catering facilities available on the estate.Visitors can enjoy Weehailes Playpark and a new takeaway ice cream parlour and coffee shop, The Dairy.The dairy premises once provided milk, cream and butter for all those who lived and worked on the estate.The team at Newhailes has developed three new visitor tours, one of which can now be pre-booked at www.nts.org.ukThe first tour explores the last  years of le at Newhailes and the trustrsquos role in saving the house and estate.The second tour sheds further light on the property, telling the tales behind the art collections and objects in the house.The final tour is targeted at families and explores the home through storytelling it is suitable for those with young children.Claire Grant, operations manager for Edinburgh, said: ldquoWersquove been taking steps to revitalise Newhailes since before  and plans were further delayed when the pandemic hit.ldquoWe wanted to create a new experience that the local community could enjoy, in addition to offering a good-quality food and drinks experience.ldquoWersquore really excited to be welcoming visitors back to Newhailes House after what has been a very long period of closure and we hope they enjoy some of our new additions, like our Dairy and Stables Cafe.ldquoSo many people love this place, and we are really pleased to be able to welcome visitors from near and far back once again.ldquoAll of our properties across Edinburgh and the Lothians have been making visits as safe as possible."Pre-booking is in place at a few sites and there are smaller groups for house tours."She said that visitors should book their slot at Newhailes in advance to avoid any disappointment.Newhailes House is open to the public for tours from Wednesday to Sunday.For more information on safety measures in place, visit nts.org.uk stories what-to-expect-when-visiting-our-places

title: hopes-open-top-bus-parade-plans-considered-best-way-celebrate-josh-taylors-win-prestonpans
story: Danielle Murphy, Joshrsquos fianceacutee, said she was looking to put plans in place for an open-top bus parade, so her partner could show off his prized championship belts to his fans, but is awaiting confirmation from East Lothian Council.: Josh Taylors fianceacutee ecstatic about his win - and excited to start wedding planningMeanwhile, Prestonpans Community Council meets on June  to discuss commemorating Joshrsquos success, but has said that any celebrations will follow coronavirus restrictions.Brian Weddell, community council chairman, said: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted for Josh and his family after his win ndash given he is Prestonpans born and bred, this is an amazing achievement for East Lothian.ldquoHe is a credit to Prestonpans.: Josh Taylor receives heros welcome onto PrestonpansGraeme Hutchison, Prestonpans Gala Day convenor and secretary, said that early discussions with partnering agencies had begun to plan a local celebration for Joshrsquos historic win.He added that there should be an official event to allow Josh to parade through the town and community members to see him and his championship belts.Mr Hutchison said that the gala committee were eager to finalise plans to celebrate the -year-oldrsquos success on behalf of the town and community.Residents have also called for Josh to be suitably honoured for his achievements, including suggestions that he should be knighted.One Facebook user said: ldquoJosh should be getting a knighthood for what he has achieved ndash the same as Chris Hoy, Andy Murray and Lewis Hamilton did in their sporting achievements.Another said: ldquoHe should be greeted by the First Minister and given the freedom of the cities of Scotland!When askedEast Lothian Council had any plans for commemorating Joshrsquos success, a council spokesperson said: ldquoWe are delighted for Josh and his family on this historic achievement and are actively considering the most appropriate way to recognise it.John McMillan, East Lothianrsquos Provost, also congratulated Josh.

title: uk-australia-trade-deal-likened-highland-clearances-snp-accused-isolationism
story: Kenny MacAskill challenged Greg Hands, UK trade minister, over the plans in the Commons this afternoon, saying the Tories ldquodonrsquot even care about Scottish sheep let alone crofters and farmers.The trade deal has raised concerns with farmers across the UK, who are worried that cheap imports of beef and lamb could see the demand for their home-grown produce dwindle.Others say they are worried about inferior products, such as hormone-injected beef coming to the UKs supermarkets - a claim the Government denies and says hormone-injected beef would never be allowed to be imported to the country.Mr MacAskill, Alba MP for East Lothian said: ldquoOver  years ago the Highland Clearances saw people shamefully replaced by sheep for landlord profits.ldquoNow this trade deal threatens to supplant those sheep with cheap imports for Tory dogma.Mr Hands replied that the production costs in the Asian markets were ldquotwice what they are in the UK adding: ldquo[This] makes it very competitive for Australia to sell into for example, markets like Japan, markets like Korea, where the domestic production price of beef is twice that in the UK.He added that the Australian lamb quota into the UK was ldquonot even fully used at the moment.Drew Hendry, the SNP MP for Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey, cited warnings from the National Farmersrsquo UnionScotland and England, saying they would struggle to competetarf-free access was granted to Australian beef and lamb exporters.Mr Hendry said the government was ldquosimply not listening to those at the sharp end and quoted NFU Scotland president Martin Kennedy, who said: ldquoOur seafood industry has already been hit hard by Brexit and now Scottish farming is next to be sacriced. Once again its Scotlands key industries which will bear the brunt of a Tory Brexit people here didnt vote for.Mr Hendry continued: ldquoNFU England warned ministers that they would struggle to compete of zero-tarfs trade on lamb or beef went ahead and the RSPCA have warned that tarf free access for Australia would betray the public, farmers, and the animals. These are just some of the warnings to government from those affected, not from politicians.ldquoWill the minister rule out tarf-free access for Australian agricultural produce However Mr Hands hit back, accusing the SNP of being ldquoisolationist and said Mr Hendry had ldquoserious questions to answer.He said: ldquoNever in  years has the SNP supported any trade deal done by either the UK, or even by the EU, even though key sectors of the Scottish economy like whiskey, like apparel, like fisheries, are dependent on trade.ldquoThey voted for no-deal Brexit, they voted against deals with our friends like Canada, Korea and South Africa. They didnt support deals with Japan or Singapore.ldquoI dont think that whatever assurances I have given you today or whatever turns out to actually be in the deal would make him and the SNP support this deal.ldquoWhen it comes to trade Mr Speaker, the SNP are isolationist and against the best interests of Scotland. ldquoPatricia Gibson, SNP MP also challenged Mr Hands, asking him why farmers could not understand ldquohow fabulous the UKrsquos deal was and adding: ldquoCould it be the case that this government is being disingenuous about the impact this deal will have on your farmers The minister said that Scotland would ldquobenefit from this deal very strongly overall.

title: crackdown-long-stay-parking-three-car-parks-among-new-waiting-restrictions-introduced

title: zans-wildlife-diary-search-fantastic-fox
story: Pointy ears, russet but vivid red fur and a bushy tail make foxes unmistakable. These animals are easily adaptable to a iety of habitats: from meadows to woods to city streets. They can also survive on a wide range of food, such as small mammals, invertebrates and fruit, but they will take advantage of food discarded by people.Foxes are social animals who live in small groups that consist of a breeding male , a femaleand their cubs. Usually, the male and female bond for le but there will be occasions when the male may seek additional mating opportunities.Mating takes place in winter and this is when foxes are most vocal. If you happen to have a window open on a winter night and you hear a loud screaming noise that sounds like a high-pitched screech, it is most definitely a fox looking for a mate and fending off its rivals.In spring, females give birth to several cubs, which become fully self-sufficient by autumn when they leave their parents. Some cubs may decide to stay with their family and they will play a big part in raising the following yearrsquos litter.My adventure with foxes started not that long ago. I was always fascinated by them but never really happened to photograph them. Occasionally, I was lucky to catch a glimpse of a fox but usually it was late in the evening or in a dense woodland, where photo opportunities are low.At the beginning of this year, I promised myself that I would find a family of foxes and get some decent shots. You may not believe it, but I spent weeks studying Google Maps in search of the best spots in East Lothian that I would visit everything marked green or looking like an open space was in scope for investigation.As spring progressed, I started to become more and more lucky with foxes. I reached the point when I could see them almost each time I left the house. I have taken multiple images, but I was never happy with them, until one dayhellipIt was a sunny Saturday morning when I decided to go out and look for deer. I visited a local meadow and quickly spotted a roe deer buck which I decided to follow. I did not manage to take any photos of the deer because as soon as I rushed after him, a beautully coloured fox crossed my path. Every day thenceforth I was coming back home with more information about the fox that I found. Finally, I was rewarded with some lovely shots in the setting sun! This is something I was dreaming of for so long! These animals are fantastic and I have completely fallen for them .Now, with lockdown eased, I hope you will have a chance to spend more time outdoors and hopefully see some lovely foxes. Evenyou donrsquot spot them on your walk, donrsquot give up! Look for some signs which may indicate of their presence: fox pooor their underground burrow .Scats are usually easily identiable as they are twisted and contain bits of fur and bones. They are deposited at prominent spots such as on footpaths, stumps, posts or rocks. The den is nothing  but a circular hollow in the groundyou are brave enough to lower yourself and snf it, you will smell a strong and unpleasant scent. Foxes secrete this smelly odour to mark their territories but it also helps to distinguish iniduals . They also have scent glands on their feet, so they mark their well-used trails as they walk ndash this is quite helpful to effectively navigate at night.If you would like to share your fox sightings with me or advise about good photography spots, please get in touch. I will also be delighted to chat anything wildle, so please do come up to say helloyou see me out and about with my camera.Speak to you next month!www.zanslenswww.facebook zanslenswww.instagram zans_lenswww zans_lens

title: plans-lodged-crematorium-near-musselburgh
story: East Lothian Council will now consider the project from the Westerleigh Group, a developer and operator of crematoria and cemeteries, with  facilities in England, Scotland and Wales.A single-storey crematorium, of around m internally, which would house a -seat chapel, is planned in the larger of two fields on the site.There would be a waiting room, accessible toilets, administration office, crematory, covered walkway and floral tribute area.Car parking providing  spaces, including six disabled accessible bays and an additional four spaces for staff parking, and memorial gardens are also planned.George Bell, regional manager for north and east from Westerleigh Group, said: "There is a pressing need for a crematorium in East Lothian."East Lothian does not have a crematorium of their own and their residents currently have to travel long journeys into Edinburgh, through busy roads, to access a crematorium."The area already has a large population base and this is going to grow further in the coming years, with some signicant new housing developments being planned."If our planning application is successful, this new crematorium will also serve the wider Edinburgh City region."We pride ourselves on creating and maintaining crematoria which are welcoming, attractive places for remembrance and reflection, and which are true assets to their local communities."The teams at all our crematoria have proudly earned a reputation for providing exceptional care and support to local people, enabling families to remember, mourn and celebrate the lives of their loved ones in a way that is uniquely personal, and we look forward to hopefully being able to bring that same high level of service to the people of East Lothian."Earlier this year, we conducted a public consultation exercise and were delighted to receive a positive response."The full planning application has now been submitted and we hope to receive a decision in early autumn."The site of the proposed development is around  acres, located north of the village of Old Craighall. It is located to the south of the slip road linking the eastbound A to the westbound A and these form the northern and eastern boundaries of the new crematorium. The western boundary is formed by Old Craighall Road and the southern boundary is formed by a minor road linking Old Craighall Road with the eastern part of Dalkeith Country Park.A planning statement, issued on behalf of the company by Holder Planning, said: "The application site is in a very accessible location. The A and the Edinburgh City Bypassconverge nearby to offer excellent levels of road access from a large surrounding catchment. The site can also be accessed via public transport."It added: "Signicant increases in population and death are projected for East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh over the next  years, which will materially increase the demand for cremation services."Also highlighted were the supposed economic benefits:The planning statement concluded: "Westerleigh have undertaken a comprehensive public consultation exercise in advance of submitting the planning application, including meetings with the Old Craighall Residents Association and Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council."There were no specic objections to the proposals, although understandably the residents of Old Craighall were keen to minimise any perceived negative impacts of the crematorium. Westerleigh have tried to respond to these points where possible."Kenny MacAskill, MP for East Lothian, said: "An expanding population and a growing elderly community mean facilities are under increasing pressure."Crematoria are things we sometimes prefer to avoid discussing but theyre essential and delays in accessing them can be distressing."Whether this site or development is appropriate is for planning officers and the planning council to decide but theres a growing need for one somewhere local."

title: tesco-trial-new-service-help-make-life-easier-customers
story: The supermarket chain is launching a new rapid delivery service which will mean it can deliver groceries to customers within an hour.The retail giant is initially trialling the Whoosh delivery service at one store and will then assess potential opportunities to expand the model.It said the one-hour service will be available for customers in selected postcodes around its Wolverhampton Willenhall Express store.The supermarket chain has seen soaring online growth during the pandemic but has so far refrained from following rivals into the on-demand grocery space.Sainsburyrsquos operates its own Chop Chop rapid delivery business, as well as services through Deliveroo and Uber Eats.Meanwhile, Waitrose recently scrapped its own Zoom rapid delivery business in favour of expanding its tie-up with Deliveroo.A raft of major grocery retailers, including Morrisons, Aldi and the Co-op, also use delivery operators such as Deliveroo and Uber Eats to reach customers.Tesco said customers will now be able to order on-demand via its app or Tesco, with products delivered by bike, moped or car, with a pound delivery fee.Chris Poad, online managing director at Tesco, said: ldquoCustomers are telling us that they would welcome the addition of a -minute delivery to their door option as part of our online grocery service.ldquoWersquoll use the pilot to understand how Whoosh could work best for both our customers and our colleagues.

title: dunbar-mums-super-effort-get-set-marathon-relay-run-groups-helped
story: Seven mums ndash and a dad ndash will cover a total of  miles this weekend in aid of Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland and Kindred.The parents met through ante-natal classes in Dunbar and are taking part in the Edinburgh Marathon Festival, held virtually due to coronavirus restrictions.Lisa Kitson, Libi Newell, Charlie Hardy and Ky Normand will form the lsquoSuper Mumsrsquo, with Catherine Devereux, Laura Bell, Sarah Callow and Jonathan Newell as the lsquoWonder Womenrsquo, with both teams taking part in the relay event.And another member of the ante-natal classes ndash Caroline Nelson ndash is providing the costumes for the runners, to ensure they look super as they complete the challenge.For Caroline, Catherine and Laura, the causes are close to their hearts. Carolinersquos son Harris and Laurarsquos son Sandy were both born with cerebral palsy, while Catherinersquos daughter Sophie has Downrsquos syndrome.Catherine, , said the two charities had both provided support.She said: ldquoOnce I was able to start looking into things, Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland were just able to provide me a lot of information, a lot of support and a lot of reassurance ndash just simply knowing they were on the end of a phoneI had any queries, be it what I need to be thinking about medically, what appointment we might be thinking or approaching coming up.It was through Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland that Catherine, who works in events, was pointed in the direction of Kindred, which supports parents of children with complex needs with advocacy, information and emotional support.Catherine added: ldquoI have been able to benefit from their counselling services, which have been a great help to me, as well as Laura.The mums all met through ante-natal classes held in Dunbar Medical Centre in the autumn of .Since their babies were born, each has kept in touch.Catherine said: ldquoWe were encouraged at the classes to share numbers and make our WhatsApp group, which has kept going since our children were born and they are now two to two-and-a-half.Together, the mums, who all live in Dunbar or previously lived in the town, are taking on the running challenge, with each lacing up their running shoes ndash and donning their costumes, with Jonathan vowing to pull on a skirtthey reach their fundraising target ndash to run four, six or eight miles.Catherine told the Courier running had proven beneficial not just physically but mentally as well.She said: ldquoI actually started doing Couch to k when my daughter was about eight weeks old.ldquoI had run before but had quite a long break from it.ldquoIt was quite a good thing for me to latch onto and I really love to run with some people as well because I had been doing it largely on my own. It is incredibly beneficial not just physically but mentally.Eddie McConnell, chief executive of Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland, wished the runners well.He said: ldquoWe are so grateful to the Dunbar Super Mums and Dunbar Wonder Women for choosing to support Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland.ldquoThe Edinburgh Marathon Relay is a huge challenge to undertake and their commitment in taking on this challenge to support our charity means a great deal to us.ldquoTheir fabulous support and the funds they have raised will help us continue to support families and people with Downrsquos syndrome reach their fullest potential.A spokeswoman for Kindred also wished each of the runners well.She said: ldquoKindred has a new dedicated four-person office based at the new Royal Hospital for Children and Young People. This is better located for East Lothian families than the old hospital, now many of the childrenrsquos services are in the same building so appointment times can be shorter.ldquoKindredrsquos hospital team offers families, emotional and practical support as well as being able to support them at clinical meetings, to understand complex medical information, so they can advocate on behalf of the family or simply help them best represent their childrsquos needs.To support the mums, go to uk.virginmoneygiving Team DunbarSuperMumsandDunbarWonderWomen

title: paul-mclennan-msp-column-saying-first-speech-holyrood
story: Irsquom fortunate to have been selected to speak early in this Parliament and Irsquom sharing the outline of my first speech, becoming your voice at Holyrood today .You expect me to deliver for you and, back in January, I promised that my priority would be protecting residentsrsquo wellbeing on our path through the pandemic recovery. My remarks will be addressing how to protect your services secure investment in existing and new facilities on which you depend and ensure that your longer-term needs are met.I stand by my promises and can report progress: the First Minister already specically identied East Lothian Community Hospital as one that would benefit from new spending on local access to healthcare.Boris Johnsonrsquos hard Brexit is damaging farming and tourism, our local food and drink industry and other businesses. As with the unseasonal weather, Brexit is outside our control in East Lothian. However, the SNPrsquos positive and pioneering vision of a green recovery is helping to underpin the countyrsquos sustainability and viability, with the Government delivering  per cent rates relief for retail, leisure, hospitality and aviation for this financial year, along with a rural entrepreneur fund to support businesses.There can be no recovery unless our children and young people flourish. Funds for summer activity schemes will benefit East Lothianrsquos communities locally and pound billion more will directly support teachersrsquo work on closing the deeply rooted attainment gap and the poverty it can perpetuate.Finally, Irsquove set up a new group of South of Scotland SNP MSPs to discuss strategic issues impacting across the region. One of these will be our share of , new houses: I know how strongly you feel about the inter-relationship between affordable housing, appropriate services, public transport and parking.My speech will demonstrate my focus on the Covid recovery in East Lothian, ensuring the county comes out of the pandemic with stronger public services and we can all look forward to a bright future.

title: musselburgh-north-berwick-swimming-pools-close-maintenance-work-completed
story: enjoyleisure welcomed back customers to North Berwick and Musselburgh swimming pools on May , following months of closure due to both the ongoing works and lockdown.The pools were both modernised with new floating floors and booms installed.When the facilities reopened, a maximum depth of . metres was in place and customers were told that more work was needed to make the new booms fully operational.The engineering contractors are toto each pool with the necessary components and materials, which have been custom designed and made for enjoyleisure, and complete the installation.In order to complete the works, specialist sub-contractor ing teams are also scheduled to be in each pool. The other facilities in each building will still be available.All of the other pools in East Lothian ndash in Dunbar, Haddington, Tranent and Prestonpans ndash will be open and available for use.Once the boom is fully operational, enjoyleisure will be able to provide iable pool depths for classes and swimming lessons, reinstate family tanks and increase the depth of the pool to provide access to the ing blocks during club sessions.Bill Axon, enjoyleisure chief executive, said: ldquoWe would like to once again express our sincere thanks for our customers patience and understanding during the upgrade of the pool facilities at Musselburgh and North Berwick.ldquoWe fully appreciate that a further interruption of swimming pool access will cause some frustration for our customers.ldquoHowever, both our maintenance partners, East Lothian Council and the engineering contractors are confident this final stage will resolve our outstanding snagging issues.ldquoI sincerely apologise for any disappointment and inconvenience caused.

title: tims-book-road-legends-chapter-16-rannoch-moor
story: ldquoWHAT did he remember  asked Finn.ldquoYoursquoll find out in another story, Irsquoll tell you it when wersquore on Rannoch Moor, the moor of broken men, said Izzy.ldquoBroken men ldquoOutlaws, Finn, or people needing to hide for whatever reason.ldquoLike the giant who killed Finn MacCoul, he fled to Rannoch Moor didnrsquot he ldquoHe did, well remembered.Izzy pointed north, where the land rose in the distance above Loch Tulla.ldquoWe have to climb to get there, itrsquos over a thousand feet above sea level.ldquoClimb  Finn retorted.ldquoDonrsquot worry, Bess will do the climbing for us, but I hope one day you will be willing to walk and climb with me, maybe we could even do the West Highland Way together.ldquoHow long is it ldquoDepends on how much you do, but in total  miles.Finn laughed with incredulity. ldquoWhat ! Naw, no way ever, sorry aunty, your walks on this trip have been long enough!And so they set off for Rannoch Moor, which meant adrive along the old road, back through the ancient Caledonian pinewood to Bridge of Orchy.As Izzy approached the bridge, her stomach sank as she relived the events of an hour ago.When Mary had made her first desperate cry to Finn, he had thankfully just closed his door so hadnrsquot heard but Izzy had. Shersquod had no choice but to rapidly set off with music playing loudly. The heartbreaking image of Mary in her rear view mirror, begging her to stop, was something she would never forget. It made her feel sick with guilt.Izzy was now desperate to speak to Ewen, to find out why the hell his mother was there in the first place after shersquod been so clear she couldnrsquot cope with being involved. And leaving the scarf, that wasnrsquot part of the plan either.Doubts and anxiety about the trip once again surfaced in Izzyrsquos mind. It had been so carefully planned to keep Finn safe, but now it seemed to be unravelling. The incident at Bridge of Orchy had unnerved Izzy to the extent she was no longer sure she could trust Ewen to keep to the arrangements they had painstakingly put together.The more she thought about it, the more she began to realise that ending the trip and taking Finn home would be the safest thing to do.But her mind was torn in a dilemma. She could see he was enjoying and benefitting from the adventure. As shersquod hoped, the landscape, the stories and immersion in nature had created a new emotional space for Finn. The Highlands were working their magic and Finn was slowly opening up his anxiety seemed less and he was managing his anger better. His regular calls to his mum were vital to maintain this, but there were signs that this trip, as Izzy had hoped, could be a seed for healing.And, besides, Finn had already made it clear he didnrsquot want the journey cut short. If she did so now, how could she explain her decision to him  She would have to make something up and he would feel so let down, probably assume he was to blame.As Izzy drove over the bridge, her mind swirled with indecision. She reached the junction with the main road, then hesitated. Head north to Rannoch Moor, or south and take Finn home  It was late afternoon now, with perhaps three hours of daylight left.ldquoCome on aunty, there are no cars, you can go.Izzy made her decision: she turned left and headed north.A distant view of the Caledonian wood was suddenly blocked by a dense plantation of Sitka spruce by the road. Then Loch Tulla reappeared into view, its banks littered with naturersquos debris, landed there during previous flooding by the loch.Before they began their ascent to Rannoch Moor, they passed the ruined castle at Achallader. Its tower was clearly visible in the distance, a jagged tooth standing defiantly but dwarfed by the mountains beyond.It was yet another fortress built by Black Duncan, this time on land taken from the Fletchers, so the story goes, by devious means. The conniving Campbell chief engineered a deadly confrontation between one of his servants and the head of the Fletchers. The sad result was the murder of the servant by the Fletcher, all part of Black Duncanrsquos plan. It was done in the heat of the moment, but murder it was, and Fletcher would hang for itcaught and tried. Duncan ensured he himself was witness to the incident, so he had Fletcherrsquos fate in his palm. So upon Duncanrsquos advice, the Fletchers fled, leaving the land to be acquired by the cunning Campbell chief, who promptly had a tower built by the farm to mark his possession of it.ldquoJust like a dog pees on lampposts to mark his territory, commented Finn.ldquoWhat an image, but yes! laughed Izzy. ldquoAnd it guards the edge of his Campbell estate, as well as the droversrsquo route. From here, we climb up to Rannoch Moor.The road curved as it climbed to give a spectacular view over Loch Tulla and the peaks of the great wall of Rannoch, a mountain boundary on the south of the moor. Izzy had travelled this way many times, but her anticipation was undiminished: Rannoch Moor is a wild place seeped in legend and history, not a few ghosts, and an unpredictable temper.Izzy pulled up at a layby on the edge of the moor and turned to look at her nephew.ldquoWersquore going on a walk, arenrsquot we  he said despondently. He looked around. It was all empty moorland with distant mountains. ldquoWe are in the middle of nowhere, aunty, what are we going to see ldquoI will be honest, Finn, itrsquos not far but it may be boggy and wet underfoot. But itrsquos a place of special meaning for me and I really want to share it with you.He looked down at his boots, then gave her an affirmative smile.ldquoOK then, I suppose so far I havenrsquot regretted going on your lsquoshortrsquo walkshellip much!They set off onto the moor but kept not far from the road. They leapt between mounds of wispy grass and bog myrtle, trying with limited success to avoid boggy areas. Soon Finn could see what he guessed was their destination: a large boulder with a tree growing from the top of it.It was a lsquogiantrsquos stonersquo but not as large as Samsonrsquos Putting Stone. Izzy climbed to the top with an ease that suggested shersquod done it before and gave Finn a hand up. They both sat under the branches of the tree, a small weather-beaten rowan, looking out to the mountains which they had passed on their journey. Cars whizzed by on the nearby road, but soon Finn became unaware of their fleeting presence as he listened to his auntrsquos words.ldquoHow it seeded in this unlikely place, I canrsquot say, she said. ldquoPerhaps a careless bird dropped a berry and couldnrsquot retrieve it. But however the seed arrived, it sprouted and grew from this small crack on the boulderrsquos summit. This tree survives on meagre ground and in an exposed position, howling winds have bent its spines. Irsquove seen it in all seasons, resplendent with berries in autumn, battered by freezing winter gales, its naked branches turned white by frost, wearing a coat of blossom in spring. Its le here seems impossible, yet it survives. Each time I pass on tour, I slow my coach and say hello under my breath. But when I am on a personal journey, I often stop and keep it company for a while.ldquoKeep it company aunty, really ldquoItrsquos alone, Finn. Trees connect with each other just as humans do, although in dferent ways of course. They crave the company of their kind, their roots intertwine as we might give each other hugs. But this beautul tree is lonesome.ldquoI donrsquot think trees get lonely, aunty, they donrsquot have feelings like we do.Izzy bent her knees up to her chin and wrapped her arms around her legs, staying silent in thought for a moment before replying.ldquoMaybe yoursquore right, Finn, perhaps itrsquos that trees can help us recognise our own feelings. You know, when we see their struggles, they remind us of our own. They are living things too and I think they can understand.Finn peered up at the tree. A few red berries hung from its wilted branches. From a distance, it had looked defiant, but close up it looked, well, precarious perhaps even anxious, clinging onto its almost bare rock for survival. He didnrsquot want to admit it out loud, but he did understand what his aunt was saying he too could feel a connection to the rowanrsquos struggle.As they sat either side of the tree squeezed on top of the boulder, Izzy told a story. Finn wasnrsquot sureit was for him or the tree probably both, he reckoned. It was a story he would long remember, more deeply than he could have imagined he would.They walked back to the car silently, carefully re-treading their steps to avoid sinking ankle deep in bog. Midges buzzed in the air but didnrsquot bother. It was getting very cool and breezy darkening clouds were making the sky seem angry.ldquoThe mood of the moor is changing, reflected Izzy out loud. ldquoYou ready to see what lies beyond that ridge Here are the links to chapters one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, , , , ,  and .

title: nicola-sturgeons-scotland-lockdown-update-need-know
story: Speaking during a lunchtime Covid briefing in Edinburgh, the First Minister confirmed thatcase numbers in the city are ldquouncomfortably high, but thereare signs both positive tests and the rate of people in hospital with the virus are stabilising.She also outlined plans to announcefurther easing of restrictions across the rest of the country.Here, we outline the key points from her briefing.Glasgow will remain in under strict Covid restrictions as the First Minister said it would be premature to move out of the current level immediately.She said a decision would be made by Wednesday at the latest on whether the city can move to Level  next Saturday.She said: ldquoThe view of the national incident management team is two-fold. Firstly, that it would be premature to move Glasgow out of Level  immediately this week while the situation remains so fragile.Photograph by Colin Mearns April " alt"East Lothian Courier: Shoppers on Buchanan Street, Glasgow today, Monday th April. title: pride-flag-flown-haddington-musselburgh-mark-pride-saltire-event
story: The flying of the rainbow flag coincided with a virtual Pride Saltire East Lothian event held online on Saturday.Pride Saltire, a Pride group for LGBTQ+ people and straight allies in East Lothian, shared videos across its social media s from its  Cockenzie House and Gardens celebration.The group, which lost founder John S Johnston and treasurer John Hein last year, honoured both men at the virtual event.A spokesperson for Pride Saltire East Lothian said: ldquoPride is a lot of things to a lot of people, and it was our late founder Johnrsquos goal to allow the people of East Lothian to experience all of them.ldquoWe are proud to continue his legacy by creating a space for LGBTQ+ people across the council and an event that allows a connection between all generations of residents, evenit is, for now, a virtual one.The group hopes it can celebrate Pride Saltire Festival in person next year.Councillor John McMillan, Provost of East Lothian, was thanked by the group for agreeing to fly the Pride flag over the two buildings on Saturday.Mr McMillan said he was delighted and proud that East Lothian Council was flying the rainbow flag.He added: ldquoWhile it is unfortunate that Pride Saltire are unable to hold the usual events due to the pandemic, it remains important to celebrate ersity within East Lothian and further afield, recognising and valuing the contribution made by the LGBTQ community.ldquoIt reinforces the message that we want everyone in East Lothian to know that they are welcome and equal citizens.The group also thanked fellow Haddington and Lammermuir councillor Shamin Akhtar.She said: ldquoThis is a fitting tribute for John, who did so much to promote Pride Saltire in East Lothian. Irsquom delighted that the online event took place over the weekend. It was a privilege to have had the opportunity to work with him and without a doubt he has left behind a legacy for us to continue supporting.Pride Scotland hopes to reconnect with the LGBTQ+ community and its allies in East Lothian for Pride Month in June.

title: peregrine-falcon-chicks-hatch-torness-power-station
story: Four peregrine falcon chicks have hatched at a rooftop nest site at EDFrsquos facility near Dunbar, making it the largest clutch for nearly a decade.In the past two decades, more than , chicks have fledged from the nuclear power stationrsquos site.Workers are able to monitor the familyrsquos progress on the companyrsquos internal network via a webcam installed in , which gives an insight into how the adults care for their young.In the initial days, the female carries out most of the brooding and feeding of the small young, while the male hunts to supply the food.After the first couple of weeks, the female shares the hunting.The young fledge after five or six weeks and are independent about two months later.Until then, the adult peregrines teach the young to hunt and handle prey in flight.Clare Galloway, from the Environmental Safety Group, said: ldquoIt has been a while since wersquove seen such a large clutch of eggs and it has been delightful watching them grow since they hatched.ldquoFavourable weather conditions have been making the job of feeding and protecting such a large family slightly easier but the parents have certainly been busy trying to meet the demands of four hungry mouths.According to the RSPB, peregrines are comparatively rare and recent estimates by the Scottish Raptor Study Group indicate that about a quarter of peregrine nests in southern and eastern parts of Scotland are subject to interference and killing.The grounds of the power station offer a safe haven for the birds where they can nest undisturbed each year and have previously attracted birds from as far away as London, an unusually long journey for a peregrine falcon.Tam Albishawi, station director, added: ldquoWe have a rich iety of wildle at Torness and it is wonderful to see the peregrinesyear after year.ldquoIrsquom delighted another four chicks look set to fledge from this successful nesting site, bringing the total for the past  years to  chicks.Torness has held the Wildle Trustrsquos Bioersity Benchmark award since  one of four sites in Scotland and the only one in East Lothian to do so.

title: secret-garden-belhaven-brewery-set-revitalised
story: Belhaven Brewery is working alongside Sustaining Dunbar to revitalise the brewery gardens by employing a community gardener.For years, the brewery gardens have been hidden behind the brew house but this partnership will see the secret gardens shared with people from Scotland and visitors from around the world.Sustaining Dunbar, the townrsquos community development trust, has worked with Belhaven to employ Caroline Bryden, who, with the help of local volunteers, will use her expertise to redesign and replant the garden areas.It is hoped the new gardens will capture the essence and history of Belhaven as a brewery, which dates back to , while also freshening up these areas, which will eventually be used as an event space in the coming years.Fiona Matheson, of Belhaven Brewery, was hopeful the partnership would prove a great success.She said: ldquoIt is great to have Caroline and the Sustaining Dunbar team on board and I look forward to seeing what we can do with this beautul space that has been hidden behind the brew house for so long.ldquoWe are working hard to open the brewery to the public very soon with a brand new visitor experience and shop, and with the addition of our secret garden, wersquore confident that Belhaven Brewery will become a fantastic place for the community to come together and enjoy what Belhaven has to offer!Caroline Bryden, the new Belhaven community gardener, was eager to get to work.She told the Courier: ldquoThe gardens have been somewhat neglected for a number of years but they hold incredible history, charm and character.ldquoI am excited to have the opportunity to rejuvenate these secret gardens and make them special for visitors once again.ldquoWe hope they will encapsulate the history of Scotlandrsquos oldest working brewery and encourage visitors back to the brewery once again.The relationship is the start of several new projects at Belhaven Brewery ahead of the summer season.Naomi Barnes, of Sustaining Dunbar, was looking forward to seeing the results of the project.She said: ldquoOur partnership with Belhaven Brewery is a really positive step forward to help Sustaining Dunbar set up new gardening outreach projects at the Belhaven Community Garden and at Dunbar Primary school, while bringing the brewery the expertise they are looking for to restore their Victorian garden.
