As I pull into a parking space, a man in a cowboy hat walks past on the pavement. He waves a cursory greeting and continues on his way. In the time it takes me to gather everything I need together, he passes me again, his step count no doubt rising with every lap of the town. Zoom. Walk. Laptop. Bake. Netflix. Repetition has become endemic over the last year, but its something Moneymore cant be accused of. There is a unique feel to the fronts of the buildings that greet me as I walk around the town. Even the post office, now boarded up, remains unbranded. googletag.cmd.push Moneymores terrain gives the town a layered effect. The pillared entrance of The Manor House provides the backdrop to the towns mini roundabout, welcoming motorists coming down the hill from Smith Street. Rusty scaffolding frames a construction site on my left as I make my way down. A woman waters potted plants in her compact front garden. The distinctive smell of curry is emanating from the two Chinese restaurants at the bottom of the hill. Shutters are down on Antonios pizza, yet to open for the day. More scaffolding sits alongside buildings in mid-construction off High Street, but no work appears to be going on today. googletag.cmd.push Along Lawford Street there are ersion signs in place as Council staff busy themselves in resurfacing the Turnaface Road. The grating sound of the road roller echoes off the houses that line the street leading back to the town centre. You could describe Moneymore as ornate. Older, unique buildings, set at dferent levels, create a layered backdrop, crowned by the spire of St John and St Treas church on the top of the hill.  The hum of a small aircraft passing overhead and the unmistakable smell of freshly-cut grass adds to the sense of a town taking new-found pleasure in the mundane.     A pregnant sky threatens rain. Taken a dip I nip into The Mane Barber Shop, where a neon sign declares the shop open for business. Owner Pauline McGarvey is at her lunch. She says reopening has not been the silver bullet the industry was hoping for. “This week has been terrible. For the first seven days [after reopening] it was great, but its taken a dip again,” she tells me. “The older folk that keep you going – your pensioners and farmers and that during the day – they havent been about the same. A vintage tractor model welcomes visitors to the town from the Tyrone side. “It was a gamble coming into a small town. You do have a bit of passing trade but youre hoping people are going to come in from the likes of Coagh, Lissan and Loup. “I said I would give it six months and see how it turns. Its fine, but its not busy. You have that fear of whether its going to come back.” Pauline has been in Moneymore three years, and until the pandemic ruthlessly attacked all businesses, things had been going well.  has seen a seismic change across all industries, driving many hair and beauty professionals off the high street altogether. “Lots of people are working from home and I have to admit, Im tempted,” she says. “Youre still going to be hit with rates, and you havent stopped paying your water bill, your electricity, your rent. “Yes, we got a bit of help, butyouve no customers in, then that money is all going to go and you still have to find wages too. “Ive seen a lot of hair and beauty people who havent gone back from the first lockdown.” Humanity adapts though, and over the last year, Pauline has embraced the situation in which the world found itself. She got married in February, and has enjoyed the extra time with her family. Keeping an eye on litter in the area. “It was the first time in my le I could actually say I was a mummy. I loved spending time with the weans,” she says. “It felt like wed a whole  years wrapped into one year. It is nice getting back though, you need the routine. Its bittersweet in a way.” Cookstown native Pauline says lockdown has really hit young people in the area hard. Her daughter, Danielle, is in Year , her entire GCSE years undertaken amid a worldwide health crisis. “Even she says she could do with another year at school,” she says. “Theyve missed a full year of preparation for the next step. Theyve been living alone in their bedroom. No formal, nothing. They werent even in school to plan it.” Its a quiet day in the barber shop, on what would normally be a busy Friday afternoon, with people popping in ahead of their weekend plans. There would have been excited chatter, the buzz of anticipation. Last minute changes of plan. Maybe even a wee drink. A look at her schedule confirms a gap of a few hours until Paulines next appointment. Without that steady flow of customers, the day can be long, lonely even. Welcome to Moneymore. Company is a two way street, and the dynamic of conversation, service and industry has been greatly missed by both barber and customer. “Even the most bald man that I have is in here every week,” says Pauline. “Two seconds would do it, but you would stretch it out to ten or  minutes, just because he likes coming in for the company. “Sometimes its just nice to get sitting down and get it done for you. Even though I have good faithful customers, I was nervous and jittery the first day back. “The amount of people who are saying its great to see you back, it gives you that wee glow. It would be nice to see a boom in Moneymore again. “I dont think anybody is going to feel anything dferent. Were all just going with the flow and trying not to stress and worry. “I think youre just going to have to wipe this year out the same as last year.”  The indicators that marked the early, panic-stricken days of the pandemic – the empty streets, closed schools, empty supermarket shelves – have long faded into memory. Only the window dressing remains. Sanitisers at shop doors. Face masks in shops. The odd discarded rubber glove on the street. All three car dealerships on the Magherafelt Road are dotted with customers as I drive past on the way home. The petrol station forecourt is hiving with people. By next Monday, theof indoor hospitality will mark another signicant step on the road to recovery. On the way out of the town, I spot a familiar cowboy hat bobbing up and down at the road side. For a village named quite literally after a field, Park is deceptively big. After crossing the bridge, I head up the hill and pull the car in opposite the Vivo and the magnicently named Rio Grande bar. Parks Rio Grande, the Faughan River, flows through the centre of the village, which this afternoon sits under an angry-looking sky. A woman walks her dog down Learmount Road, her face set against the stf breeze that is swishing through the trees surrounding the village. The scene on Learmount Road leading up the hill. Rain starts to fall as a mother guides her toddler out the doors of the Vivo, one hand clutching hers and the other gripping the bottle of juice he has just been bought. googletag.cmd.push A large plastic ice cream cone sits hopefully outside the shop. Up the hill comes a learner driver seemingly on a lesson. She stops outside Learmount Resource Centre and disappears into the building, before emerging with her child in tow to resume her lesson. A delivery driver pulls into the yard of Devine Kitchens. He s to his cab and pulls out a hammer. Things must be getting serious. As I cross the bridge, I spot the wheel from an old watermill by the river side, almost reclaimed by its surroundings. A remnant of an  flax mill known as Quigleys Mill. googletag.cmd.push Perhaps the most clear view of the mill is from the top of the hill outside Park Hardware and DIY. Greg McElhinney and Matthew Devine. Inside, owner Greg McElhinney says the last year has been busy. “With construction and everything  closing down last April, we were very busy, which was good for us because people from the local area were able to do home projects,” he tells me. “The weather was good as well, so youd a lot of painting and decorating – fences and gardens and stuff like that – going on. “People were happy there was a local business still operating, because a lot of the bigger hardware stores had closed.     “It got to the stage when it was hard to source materials because suppliers were closed until June time, but people were happy enough to occupy their time. They had nothing  to do.” The remains of Quigleys Mill, Park. Parks postal area recorded an increase in Covid cases last week, and despite the attachment to Derry city skewing the numbers, Greg admits there is still a degree of worry locally. “The majority of the population feel we still have to be serious about this. Its drilled into everybody at this stage, like putting your seatbelt on in the car,” he says. “The worry now is were straddling the Donegal border to a certain extent and case numbers are very high either side of it. “There is more positivity now than there was maybe six weeks ago though. Society is opening up again, and the vaccinations are a positive thing.” Covid has taken its toll on rural le too, and compliance with regulations has come at a social cost for village communities. “Where were based is very much a rural area, with a lot of the farming community and tradesmen and stuff,” says Greg. “You get some people who, by chance, meet up outside the shop here and have an opportunity to have a chat that maybe havent seen each other in a few months. “Those guys would have been at markets or farm meets every week, or pubs, but now you see them sitting out there for half an hour chatting to each other. “The social aspect, face to face, is the biggest thing. “The local community group have done a lot of work with the walkways there over the past number of years, which is very good.” Caroline Lynch and Catriona Doughty from Learmount Community Development Group. The local community group to which Greg refers is Learmount Community Development Group, which is nestled down a lane next to the entrance to Learmount Forest. Over the last year, Caroline Lynch and Catriona Doughty have noticed a big increase in people using Parks hidden gem. “We would have come down here some mornings and that car park would be full,” says Caroline. “Our secret Learmount Forest isnt a secret any more, and thats great, because everybody wants out, and weve had drop-ins coming from that.” “The forest has been fantastic for people being able to get out and safely meet their neighbours,” adds Catriona. “Theyll maybe call in at quiet times to have a socially distanced cup of tea. That social aspect has been missed, they are missing company and casual conversation.” Caroline feels the experience of the last year has sharpened focus on the issue of loneliness that had been hiding in plain sight. “We had a man who lives alone and had been sick for two or three days,” she says. “He hadnt been out and had no food in the house, so thankfully we were able to help with that. “You just know people are lonely and looking to get out again, but at the same time are a bit anxious about it. “Theyre happy to take the summer out of it and see what happens. There is certainly a lot of loneliness, isolation and depression though. “You could obviously be in the middle of a housing site and still be lonely, but when you see some of the people on their own, up a lane, they see nobody. They barely even see the postman now.” Working with both young and old people, the group have seen the effect the pandemic and its associated lockdowns have had on both generations.  “A lot of our work is with older people, and whilst theyre saying theyre fed up, some of them are getting a wee bit set in their ways,” says Caroline. “You just know by talking to them. We had a woman who always came in every week, even when it was bad, and she hasnt been in about two months. “Its highlighted how much we miss the social side of things, not being able to get out and meet friends. Even for the youth. “People always think all they need is their phone, because thats all theyre sitting on, but you can see now how the youth are crying out as much for social contact as any other generation.” There is hope though, that with the vaccines roll out and the upcoming warmer weather, that the group will be able to run some of their usual summer events. “We are looking at putting together a summer programme, but wed be a bit nervous ourselves about bringing a group of people into the room,” says Caroline.  “It would be perfectthere was good weather, because it will be planned outdoors. If the weather is bad, well take it over to Park hall, because its a bit bigger than here. “We have funding for dancing and music, which I think people would love to hear. Wed love to have tables out there on a nice evening, with a bit of a barbecue and a bit of music. “Youd like to think by September, we should be able to get going.” On the way back through the village, the shutters are half up on the Rio Grande as preparations continue inside. By the time you read this it will have reopened its doors. Hospitality has ed throughout the county, another step on the road to recovery. The farmers outside Greg McElhinneys store now have somewhere  to shoot the breeze. For the next few weeks at least, Covid fears will be drowned out by clink of glasses, the audible relief of the repressed socialite and the laughter of friends reunited. Dancing, however, is still prohibited under the regulations. It may need to be done across Parks Rio Grande, rather than inside it.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. With six players who played in their minor final win over Ballinascreen, the Martins clinched the second of their refixed  finals in an exciting U decider on Friday night in Loup. Murtagh stole the show an unbelievable display from the wing forward, with - of his tally coming from play. A game that could have went anyway for the most of the game until the St Treas and St Johnswere reduced to  men and it was an uphill battle after that. googletag.cmd.push The Martin’s went five points up before St Treas and John’s got off the mark, but they soon settled in and it was a close contest after that with the Martin’s always keeping their noses in front until two goals from magic Orzel turned the game on its head.  A slicker Martin’s, led by Murtagh, didn’t panic and plugged away to get back on top and when they did they were not going to be denied. People are being given the chance to have their say on how Derry can recover from the Covid pandemic. Derry City and Strabane DistrictCouncilis seeking the views of the public to its recently-published draft Performance ImprovementPlanfor  . The councilhas a legal obligation to produce a Performance ImprovementPlanthat strives towards continuous improvement in the quality of le of its citizens. The first draft is currently available online andthe councilis keen to get the views of the public. A council spokesperson said: “Among the improvement objectives set out in the draftplanare to put into place a range of initiatives to increase employment opportunities and stimulate economic growth and to assist with theof healthy lestyles through participation in leisure, sport and physical activities. googletag.cmd.push “Theplanalso includes a commitment to create a greener, cleaner and more attractive local environment and sets outplansto deliver improved customer support services and processes. “A key objective set out in the ImprovementPlanis theCouncil’s commitment to deliver a dynamic recoveryplanthat will provide a proactive response to the challenges presented by the COVID  pandemic. “Theplanwill put measures in place to enhance the social, economic and environmental well-being across theCouncildistrict.” A copy of the draft plan is available on thecouncilwebsite. Two organisations in Derry are to share more than pound, in funding from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland. The Arts Council this week announced funding ofpoundm for arts organisations throughout Northern Ireland. The Arts Council’s Annual Funding Programmeis the most signicant allocation of public funding for the arts in Northern Ireland each year. Void Gallery in Derry is to receive pound,, while Greater Shantallow Community Artsis to be allocated pound,. GSCA aims to provide direct access to the arts for those living in disadvantaged communities. GSCA is core funded by the Arts Council of Northern Ireland which enables the organisation to offer a year-round programme of creative activities benefitting over  people every week, delivered from their community arts centre, Studio . googletag.cmd.push The local group has received Arts Council funding to support the employment of a dance officer to develop their dance classes. Void Gallery’s programme focuses on the collaborative nature of art and its ability to add to artistic discourse through exhibitions, events, discussions and partnerships. Through their commissions they work with a network of arts organisations both nationally and internationally to create specic projects. Liam Hannaway,chair of the Arts Council of Northern Ireland, welcomed the latest funding support. “This year’s annual allocation of exchequer and National Lottery funding is largely standstill for most of our key arts organisation,” he said. “In order to mitigate the continuing impact of Covid-, we have already released upfront payments of % of last year’s grant to  applicants. googletag.cmd.push “This offers an element of stability to many amidst current programming and strategic uncertainty, as the sector prepares to reopen. Commenting on the department’s funding allocation to ACNI, Communities Minister, Deirdre Hargey,said, said such support was an important part of the foundations on which the work of our vital arts and creative sector is built. “These awards come at a point where the Executive has agreed a series of important relaxations that will make a real dference for participation in the arts and with the Culture, Arts and Heritage Recovery Taskforce beginning its work. “Taken together these represent an important contribution to supporting the peopleand organisations who work across the arts to be able to do their important work.     “I recognise the pressure that continues to be felt financially, creatively and at a personal level across the creative community, even as we begin the process of reopening and recovery. “I also recognise that more support will be needed this year and so I was particularly pleased to welcome the Executive’s decision last week to allocate a further round of poundm Covid funding to Arts, Culture and Heritage to support the social recovery.”  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A Derry family is continuing to fundraise in memory of their son who tragically passed away from cancer when he was just  years old. The Logue family will today be hosting a k run and walk and raffle, raising vital funds for Young Lives vs Cancer and Marie Curie – two charities close to the family’s hearts. Paddy and Theresa Logue from Gobnascale were devastated when their son Gerard passed away in , the day before his th birthday. They set up the Gerard Logue Memorial Fund in his honour and have raised more than pound, for Young Lives vs Cancer. googletag.cmd.push Gerard was diagnosed with a rare cancer of the muscles when he was , and after  months of treatment he sadly passed away. Theresa said: “Not a day goes by without us thinking of him.” Paddy said: “We are so very grateful for the help we received from Young Lives vs Cancer, the support to Gerard and the whole family was fantastic. “You don’t realise you need that much support when your child is diagnosed with cancer. “Families get even more support now with the addition of the charity’s Homes from Home and free accommodation provided close to the hospital. It is a hidden gem that needs awareness.” googletag.cmd.push In , the family were supported by the charity again when Theresa and Paddy’s granddaughter Bella, aged six, went through cancer treatment too. Paddy said: “Bella had a hard time with the treatment but it was great to have Paul’s House – a slipper walk away from the The Royal Victoria Hospital for Sick Children to stay at whilst she received her treatment. “It would have been a -mile round trip otherwise or a costly stay at a hotel. She is doing great now, she loves Gaelic football and is a bundle of energy. “Young Lives vs Cancer relies on donations and it has been so good as a family to be able to fundraise annually.     “Each year the support has grown, we now have sons and daughters of people that first took part. “Last year we held a virtual concert that raised more than pound, and this year we decided to do a k walk run over bank holiday weekend with a raffle – the top prize being pound. “The raffle will be held at Molly’s Bar Iona House, Spencer Road at pm sharp. “We are fundraising for two charities this year as sadly Molly Moran, a treasured committee member of the Gerard Logue Memorial Fund passed away last year. title: ‘Wee Joe’ honoured for commitment to Ballynahinch
story: FOR the first fty years of Ballynahinch Rugby Club one name was synonymous with the club, a constant presence as they established themselves on the rugby landscape.That name was Joseph Kirkpatrick Carlisle mdash lsquoWee Joersquo to everyone who knows him in rugby circles in Ulster, Ireland and all over the world.He is a founder member of the club and fulfilled the role of first XV captain, match secretary, chairman, groundsman and tour manager, as well as having the honourable distinction of being the only man to have served twice as president.He was an ever-present on the club council and served as club representative to the Ulster Branch for  years until .These bare facts hide the colossal influence of Joe in the early years of the club as he drove it on from very humble beginnings in  to a much sought-after Townsrsquo Cup triumph in .Despite his diminutive stature, Joe was a wing forward on that team and was known for his relentless training regime. His -year playing career ended on the Evergreens in the early s.Joersquos role as match secretary for twenty years was absolutely crucial given his unique ability to dig out players when all seemed lost, recruiting players at Down High on Saturday mornings to fulfil fixtures later that day.Complete strangers would often turn up for second  matches in the early days saying that Joe had instructed them to turn up and play.Despite his tireless work on behalf of the club, Joersquos greatest pleasure throughout his rugby le has been the friends he has made along the way.A keen tourist, he has travelled the world to follow rugby and even took in some of the Lions fixtures in South Africa in .He was tour manager on the legendary  Ballynahinch tour of Canada, as well as partaking in a few trips away with the Evergreens.When promotion to the All-Ireland League was secured in , Joe was a regular spectator at games all over the country and could be seen at every first XV home fixture in his familiar spot on the m line until very recently.The flat cap, long navy Adidas coat, familiar cough and half pint of Harp should conjure up an image of Joe to everyone who knows him, and to countless others who have passed through the Ballynahinch club in recent years not knowing the huge influence he has had on their rugby.Joe is the recipient of the coveted Spence Cup this season. He is truly deserving of this award and it is le-affirming to see that friendships gained through team sports run deep as Sam Robinson, himself a Spence Cup winner, acts as carer for Joe as his health deteriorates.Rugby it seems, is giving something back to one of itrsquos finest local servants.On behalf of the Spence family, Emma Rice commened: ldquoThe Spence Cup is given to a member who shows an example of commitment to the rugby club. Joe Carlislersquos service to the club in time and deed epitomises this.ldquoA society grows great when old men plant trees whose shade they know they will never sit in. We are often guilty of not noticing a tree that gives the shade we sit under, she continued.ldquoPlayers of today may no longer see as much of that familiar face on the m line at Ballymacarn Park, but they will see the roots, the structure, the shade and benefit from what wee Joe once planted. Thank you and congratulations, Joe..prettyPhoto

title: Business owners join forces in their love of baking
story: THEY became virtual supporters of each otherrsquos business during lockdown mdash now two women bakers are working together to raise money for dementia research.Ciara Van Vogt, the owner of Margaretrsquos Cottage BB in Ardglass and Sharon Campbell from Mrs Crsquos Home Kitchen in Dundrum, have raised pound, so far for the Alzheimerrsquos Society from an online bake sale.They supported each otherrsquos business efforts through lockdown last year by connecting on social media but did not meet in person until March.When they did, the two ladies struck up an immediate friendship and decided to put their skills together and collaborate on a project.Sharon said: ldquoDuring lockdown charities have really suffered and there are many worthy causes out there, we both agreed it was hard to support just one.ldquoBoth businesses support their own inidual local charities and will continue to do, but we chose to support an Alzheimerrsquos charity because we both know many people affected by this awful disease.Ciara is a carer for her elderly mother, Mrs Eithne Fitzsimons, who was diagnosed with Alzheimerrsquos disease four years ago.ldquoI lose a bit of Mum every week, and sometimes Mum doesnrsquot know who I am, said Ciara.ldquoLockdown has stopped support groups and activities for people with dementia. Itrsquos been very challenging for carers and their loved ones, and people often forget that carersrsquo lives are adversely affected too.ldquoImagine having a spouse or parent who no longer recognises you and who due to this awful disease you no longer recognise.One of the things that resonates with both women is the thought of any loved one losing all our precious memories.Ciara continued: ldquoResearch into the causes of, and treatment for dementia is critically important but not a priority for UK governments.ldquoWe would love to see this dreadful disease eradicated for future generations. We both have strong ties to Northern Ireland, being from here, although we both spent time living and working in England and Scotland before moving home to settle back in Co Down. Our mutual love of baking and cooking was how we met and became friends.The two bakers organised a virtual bake sale to raise money for dementia research.However they soon realised that due to geography not everyone could buy their fabulous baking, so they set up a JustGiving page to run alongside the bake sale.ldquoPlanning the challenges of a bake sale during lockdown was fun, so too was choosing some of our most popular products to sell to raise money, said Sharon.ldquoThe menu proved so popular. Within ten days we both realised we wouldnrsquot get much sleep as baking for Alzheimerrsquos became a top priority.Early mornings and late nights meant that customers received their sweet treats and funds are still being raised by the pair.If you want to check out their Just Giving page, details are: https:www.justgiving fundraising sharonandciarasbakesale and both ladies can be found on Facebook and Instagram..prettyPhoto

title: Campbell on form as Duns claim derby win
story: DUNDRUM firsts defeated derby rivals Downpatrick by  runs on Friday evening to continue their push for a semi-final spot in the T Shield.Dundrum travelled to the Strangford Road after their pitch was deemed unplayable after heavy rain with the home side winning the toss and, on a cold damp evening, chose to field first.Dundrum opened with Greg Hutley and Stuart Campbell while Downpatrick opened the bowling with Justin Rea and Marty Gartland.Dundrum got off to a fast start adding  for the first wicket inside the first six overs before Hutley was dismissed for  off the bowling of Gartland.Dundrumrsquos run rate began to halt as a result of the combination of good Downpatrick bowling and a slow outfield.Terry Hutley and Campbell added  for the next wicket before Dundrum lost four quick wickets in the form of Campbell , Hutley , James Martinand Joel Maguire .This left Dundrum  for five with Downpatrick on top as Ian Wright and Gavin McNerlin added  for the next wicket before another clump of wickets fell to leave Dundrum  for nine after  overs.McNerlin managed to get Dundrum to  for nine from their  overs as he finished on  not out.The pick of the Downpatrick bowlers was James Ferguson who finished with figures of  for  from his four overs and the game was very much in the balance heading into the second innings.Downpatrick opened with brothers Michael and Daniel Carson whilst Dundrum elected to open the bowling with Davy Glover and Daniel Kearsley.Similar to Dundrumrsquos innings, Downpatrick got off to a fast start, putting on  for the first wicket inside the first six overs.The Downpatrick men combined well and began running fluently between the wickets to put the pressure on the Dundrum bowlers.Daniel Carsonwas dismissed off the bowling of Davy Glover after a good catch by Andrew Foster in the dee, with Paul Linehan next to the crease to join Michael Carson.Linehan looked to be aggressive, hitting a big six to keep the pressure on Dundrum as the two batsmen took the score to  for  inside nine overs.However, Dundrum began to fight back through Campbell and McNerlin. The former dismissed both Carson and Linehan in the same over to swing the match back in favour for Dundrum.This started a Downpatrick collapse with the last eight wickets falling for only  runs. McNerlin finished with figures of  for  from four overs while Campbell finished with  for  from his four overs, completing a -run win for Dundrum.It was a fantastic fight back for Dundrum and Downpatrick will know they let the game get away from them.Dundrum would like to thank Downpatrick Cricket Club for hosting the game with the match ball sponsored by Aiden McCabe from AMC building.Dundrum -Downpatrick  all outT SHIELD.prettyPhoto

title: Despair for Down in second defeat
story: DOWN were second best to a Meath side who ran out comfortable winners by a margin of seven points at Armaghrsquos Athletic Grounds on Sunday.Down were forfeiting their home advantage as a result of breaching the GAArsquos Covid- regulations during lockdown and perhaps that, coupled with the torrid weather conditions, attributed to their performance.Paddy Tally signicantly reshuffled his starting line-up following their opening day defeat against Mayo in Castlebar.The Down manager made a total of five changes, with goalkeeper Marc Reid and captain Darren OrsquoHagan the most notable of them all.Meath began the sharper of the two sides, but Down could not fault lady luck as their opponents were reduced to  men following a Eoin Harkey black card.The red and black outfit failed to take advantage of their additional man as Meath began scoring points through Cathal Hickey, Mathew Costello and Andrew Colgan.Corey Quinn did manage to score two points before the quarter for the Mourne county, but he also failed to convert a goal scoring chance which set the tone for the afternoon.The game was not away from Down at this stage as Quinn added to his tally alongside scores from Paul Devlin and Ryan McElroy to trail by only two points at half-time.It was a reverse in roles for the second half, as this time it was Down player Jonny Flynn who was shown the black card, leaving his side down a man.Unlike Down, Meath took full advantage of the extra shirt on the pitch and Cillian OrsquoSullivan buried two goals just before and after the third quarter to put the contest out of sight.Referee Niall Cullen was kept busy with his cards, this time displaying a red to Downrsquos Gerard McGovern to close out a miserable afternoon for Tallyrsquos men.Down now travel to Mullingar this Sunday, where they face off against Westmeath at Cusack Park.Down: M Reid P Fegan, G McGovern, P Murdock, P Laverty, D OrsquoHagan, C Mooney, R McEvoy , J Flynn, J Guinness, B B OrsquoHagan , D Savage for Quinn Meath: A Colgan , S Lavin, C McGill, C Hickey , E Harkin, S McEntee, D Keogan, B Menton, P Harnan, E Devine , B McMahon , M Costello , J Morris , T OrsquoReilly , C OrsquoSullivan .Subs: R Ryan for Harkin , J Wallace for OrsquoReilly , E Wallacefor Hickey , J Scully for McMahon , J Conlon for Morris , D Campion for OrsquoSullivan , G McCoy for McEntee Referee: Niall Cullen Down -Meath -NFL DIVISION A.prettyPhoto

title: Dozens walk in memory of Seaforde Special Olympian
story: UPWARDS of  people took part in a charity walk around Castlewellan Lake on Saturday in memory of Seaforde man Glenn McBride, who died  weeks ago.Glennwas a medalled Special Olympics competitor who enjoyed soccer and basketball, playing both to a high standard.He was a popular member of of Down Special Olympics Club in Downpatrick and Shimna Stars Special Olympics Club in Newcastle.Glenn won a soccer gold medal with Team Down at the Area Games in Belfast in  and was a member of the Ulster soccer team at the Ireland Games the following year. He won a basketball gold medal with Team Ulster at the Ireland Games in .His friend Harry Walsh organised the walk in aid of the Belfast Cancer Centre to honour Glennrsquos commitment to the people who looked after him so well when he was ill.While Glenn had originally wanted to host a charity football match, he suggested a sponsored walk instead as it would be more Covid-aware.He never got the chance to host the walk but Harry continued it with it in his memory.Harry described his friend as having ldquothe kindest heart and soul who was always considerate to others.ldquoHe was never judgemental, and his passing has shown what a fantastic inspirational friend he was to many, he wrote on Facebook.ldquoHis passing is a huge loss and has left a massive hole in the lives of his family, his friends, me personally and this world in general..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 30%2C 2011
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Down District could be in line for a multi-million pound investment package which has the potential to create several hundred new jobs.Private talks between a number of key players in the financial and construction industries have been taking place over the past number of months and a major announcement is expected shortly.The core of the talks focused on Downpatrickrsquos poundm business park and an investment package of several million pounds has been put together to unlock its huge potential.It has emerged that plans are at an advanced stage to build a number of purpose built units at a -acre site at the Belfast Road complex to entice major companies to set up businesses in the area.The plan is to have business units in place to ensure that when investors do express an interest in coming to the area, they can move in almost immediately.One of the key men involved in the talks is local councillor Harvey Bicker and he has no doubt the amount of finance which has been put together can pave the way for ldquountold opportunities in the area.He has been able to secure the support of major financial players who have already agreed with the IDB to build the so-called advance factories at the Downpatrick business park.It is understood one major company is already interested in relocating its business to the Belfast Road site and several others are also believed to have expressed an interest in the -acre complex.NEWCASTLE mdash A teacher at Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle has this week discovered she is in a class of her own.A favourite amongst pupils, work colleagues and parents, Karen Caulfield, head of maths at the college, has been shortlisted for the prestigious Teacher of the Year award.The Rostrevor woman had been secretly nominated by several teaching colleagues and by parents of her students.According to school principal Kevin Lambe, Mrs Caulfieldrsquos colleagues entered her for the award as they were so impressed by her leadership qualities, her ability to inspire students, her innovative work and her organisation of the schoolrsquos numeracy strategy.ldquoMrs Caulfield is a wonderful teacher and a real asset to our college. Her colleagues all say that she has a real gt for helping students have confidence in their own ability, he said.KILLYLEAGH mdash The charred remains of Killyleagh GAA club, gutted in a blaze in the early hours of Monday morning, are to be demolished.The fire completely engulfed the clubhouse at Wolfe Tone Park, and it has been decided by club and Down County Board officials to demolish the clubhouse instead of refurbishing it.The building has been lying vacant since last year after the Wolfe Tone Club encountered financial dficulties and its teams were withdrawn from the Down leagues.The blaze, which spelled the final fate of the building, took place in the early hours of Monday morning.Downpatrick fire crews were alerted shortly after am and on arrival at the scene had to call for assistance from Ballynahinch and Comber to help control the flames.It took firemen more than four hours to bring the fire under control and by am on Monday morning all that was left of the vacant building was a crumbling shell and an acrid smell of hot ash.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A Ballynahinch student is flying high after gaining his private pilotrsquos licence.After months of gruelling training Phillip Miskimminrsquos dream of piloting a plane for a prestigious airline and travelling the world is well within his reach.As most  year-olds hop into the seat of a car, Phillip is now able to jump into the cockpit of a light aircraft, but the ambitious high-flyer is not going to settle at that.He is determined to one day become a flight captain for a commercial airline, flying passengers to destinations across the globe.Phillip was trained for his private pilotrsquos licence at Aldergrove Airport and was funded by a scholarship which he won from the Guild of Air Pilots and Navigators.The successful teenager was also the winner of the John Landymore trophy which is awarded to the most outstanding scholarship winner.Currently an aeronautical engineering student at Queenrsquos University, the former pupil of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick has the world at his feet.The young pilot has had a passion for flying since he was  and is thrilled that he can now actually fly an aircraft.KILLOUGH mdash Raised from the ashes by the local community, Killough Hall once again stands proudly in the heart of the village.Local people, young and old, flocked to the newly built youth and community centre at Palatine Square to celebrate itrsquos official opening on Friday, four years after an overnight fire left it completely gutted.In an admirable community drive local people have resurrected the building which had been part of the local village for generations.Well known author historian and Killough native, Dr Maurice Hayes, officially unveiled the new centre which will provide leisure facilities, further education courses and a social venue for all.Reminiscing about his childhood days when he used to go to the hall every Saturday afternoon for his ldquohated dance classes, a jovial Dr Hayes said it was wonderful that the hall has been restored.Mr Hayes said everyone who worked so hard to get the hall back on its feet have helped bring a new heart and le into the building and a new heart and le into Killough.STRANGFORD ndash Bank Holiday Monday was a busy day for local RNLI and Coastguard members, with two call-outs off the County Down coastline.The first incident took place at around .pm in Strangford Lough when a sailing dinghy, with three men onboard, capsized close to The Long Sheelagh rock.One of the men was rescued by a passing fishing vessel while the others were clinging to the boatrsquos hull when Portaferry leboat arrived. A Wessex helicopter from RAF Aldergrove joined the rescue and members of Portaferry Coastguard were called to assist.ldquoAll three casualties were winched to the helicopter and taken to shore close to Kircubbin Sailing Club. None of the men, who were wearing wet suits and le jackets, were seriously injured and it is believed adverse weather conditions caused the boat to overturn, said a Coastguard spokeswoman.As this incident was closing and the helicopter had just landed the casualties, Coastguards then received information that two young boys were being blown offshore in a small boat close to Ballyhornan.ldquoThe helicopter was re-tasked and itrsquos crew stood by with members of the Ardglass Coastguard unit, but the children, who were aged  and , were able to make it back to shore safely, she added.SAINTFIELD ndash Teenagers in Saintfield are being blamed for vandalising stone walls and blocking a river in the town.Concerned residents in Shrewsbury Dale have voiced their concern about what is happening and asked local councillor Robert Burgess to address the problem.Mr Burgess said residents and local farmers are becoming increasingly concerned at the behaviour of the teenagers and highlighted the importance of making them realise the error of their ways.He explained that over the past number of months, children have punched holes in local hedgerows to gain access to fields adjacent to the Shrews-bury Dale housing development.ldquoLivestock and horses have been in the fields concerned and we have to be thankful they did not escape as a result of the childrenrsquos action, Mr Burgess continued..prettyPhoto

title: New £50k play park at Downpatrick school
story: A DOWNPATRICK primary school has officially opened its new pound, playground and garden facilities.St Colmcillersquos Primary School in Glebetown Drive now has a new sensory garden called the Rainbow garden, an outdoor play park and a new welcome garden at the schoolrsquos front door.School principal Stephen Austin said the facilities were financed by pound, raised by the careful management of the school budget and pound, from the schoolrsquos Parents, Teachers and Friends Association .Planns were drawn up last June and the work by contractor, All Play Ballynahinch, began in January.Mr Austin explained: ldquoThe school is set on a spacious site with several large green areas.ldquoI wanted to maximise the learning potential of our school site to improve pupils holistic learning experiences, particularly within the areas of outdoor education, activity based and play based learning which are essential areas of the curriculum and so important in eliciting enthusiasm in learning and developing key skills in core areas such as literacy, numeracy, ICT and STEAM.ldquoI also wanted to enhance facilities for our wonderful children who deserve the best and who were disadvantaged by interruptions to their schooling in recent times due to the Covid pandemic. But also to strengthen school community and pride in our fantastic school.Mr Austin paid tribute to the schools PTFA for its fundraising, to the board of governors for support and a group of volunteers who worked on the welcome garden.ldquoThe team spirit that has been displayed throughout this project has been uplting and a reflection of the strong school community that exists within St Colmcilles Primary School, he said.ldquoThe board of governors have supported this project throughout and are committed to a cycle of continuous improvement of all aspects of the school, especially its facilities and resourcesHe continued: ldquoThe PTFA have fundraised relentlessly through organising ious raffles, draws, bingos and hampers. They have enjoyed amazing support from our parents and the whole school community who all have been very generous. So far, they have contributed pound, to the project which has allowed us to go the extra mile with more extensive resources and a very high spec finish in the ious areas.He said that the welcome garden was created almost exclusively by volunteers such as grandparent Stephen Vaughan, who built the planter boxes, the garden furniture was designed and constructed by brothers Lawrence and Gareth Blaney, the circular stone planter built by parent Fergus Rooney , grounds work was carried out by Pascal Magee and planting by Bill Carew. Plants and shrubs were provided at a discounted rate from Cunningham Flowers in Dundrum.The schoolrsquos head of outdoor education, Sean McReynolds, oversaw the project with building supervisors Brian Tweedie and Bill Carew, classroom assistant Ryan Craig and Gemma Vaughan, the schoolrsquos eco co-ordinator.Parent Roisin McKenna, who along with Andrea McMenamin, Natasha Shields and Rosaleen Cunlfe leads the PTFA committee, said that they had enjoyed ldquoamazing support from parents, the wider school community and local businesses.Roisin said: ldquoThe ethos of our PTFA is about "making memories" and this is always at the forefront of our fundraising. We wanted the money we raised to benefit every child in the school and therefore the school have all the children timetabled for outdoor learning everyday.ldquoThis makes our fundraising all worthwhile when you see happy children playing daily outdoors.The PTFA organised fundraising initiatives like bingo, raffles, hampers and draws which have allowed the school to further develop the footprint of the planned facilities for the children.The schoolrsquos Rainbow garden includes a tepee, a water wall for directing and controlling the flow of water, an activity table, a water and sand tray, outdoor shelter, sensory plants with a vivid colour or smell and plastic coated activity table where children can paint use sand and textiles to show their learning.Therersquos also an outdoor classroom which can hold up to  pupils and adults with bespoke seating and a blackboard with outdoor musical equipment.Itrsquos contained within ranch style fencing and is very popular with all the schoolrsquos pupils, particularly those within its learning support centres, many of whom have complex sensory needs.The new play park contains swings, slide, climbing tower, monkey bars, balance equipment, ropes, seesaws seating and planting areas.Children are timetabled at break and lunch times and for certain lessons throughout the day.An eye-catching circular stone planter has been filled with a iety of shrubs and trees in the new Welcome garden.Therersquos also a bespoke reading area overlooking four large rectangular sleeper planter boxes filled with beautul summer flowers, a solar powered water fountain, a bird bath and bird tables..prettyPhoto

title: Politicians gather to mark Northern Ireland centenary
story: CROSSGAR marked Northern Irelandrsquos centenary on Monday with a special event.A number of local politicians including South Down MLA Harry Harvey and Rowallane councillors Billy Walker, Terry Andrews, Robert Burgess and Kathryn Owen met in the village square with each holding a torch which symbolised what happened in Crossgar a century ago when the province was formed.On that occasion, a bonfire was lit in the square by local residents to celebrate the creation of Northern Ireland on election night of the new parliament.The local MP was Sir James Craig, the first Prime Minister of Northern Ireland who had personal ties to Crossgar and had been its Westminster MP since .To mark the national and local event, local politicians from all parties were invited to hold a flame in a triangular shape on Monday symbolising the fire that was lit on the birth of the country in .Cllr Walker said he was delighted to have been invited to Crossgar to take part in the special event to mark Northern Irelandrsquos th birthday..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes paid to Down Rec soccer legend Jim Connolly
story: JIM Connolly died on April  after a hard fought two year battle with illness.His passing was marked by a phenomenal level of tributes.Social media,work colleagues, team-mates and opponents alike expressed how well liked and respected he was in all walks of le.He was first and last a family man whether it was his brothers and sisters, Angie and his children or his beloved grandchildren.However Coot, as he was known, had another family which he held dear. He had been a vital cog in the Down Rec team which enjoyed great success in the late Seventies.But it was and remains the case that the Down Rec experience is defined by the enduring friendships which have stood the test of time.Coot grew up in Stream Street and the reason he knocked back opportunities to perform at levels his talent merited may well lie there.That part of Downpatrick had three working class housing developments, Ardpatrick and Russell Park with Stream Street and Ibrox Park in the middle.Ibrox was their playground, the place where Coot first kicked a football.He was a Stream Street kid and it seems he never wanted to be anything .When Jim Prior took him to Down Rec, it was a marriage made in heaven.In that dressing room you had another more senior Stream Street kid. Coot would have idolized Tony lsquoDartrsquo Curran in those days as he was the leader of the pack.Russell Park resident Barney Fitzsimmons was there too, a swashbuckling goalscorer who enjoyed something akin to Roy of the Rovers status at the time.Then you had the late great Paddy lsquoGeordyrsquo Galbraith, who combined a hard man reputation with a heart of gold.Peter Mulhall was another player he would have admired, a winner who proved the perfect centre back partner for the laid-back Coot.The total respect he had for them was accorded to all of us even though he was a better player than any of us. That was Coot Connolly.Prior realized that he needed to recruit from outside Downpatrick to fulfill his ambitions for the club and over a period of time he recruited players from Portaferry, Strangford, Ardglass, Dundrum, Crossgar, Saintfield, Killyleagh and Ballygowan.They were brought in for their ability but Jim couldnrsquot have known that the erse personalities therein would create the perfect storm in the dressing room.Neither could he have anticipated the level of support which flowed from those villages in the seasons to come.Dressing rooms are bastions of banter and slagging and with Dart jester-in chief, the group relished every minute they spent together.The five strong Portaferry contingent proved to be a vital ingredient, their earthy Ards humour and the opportunities their accents provided for slagging sealing their popularity.Jackie Leckey and Barney Ross brought another dimension willing as they were to join in the shenanigans on and off the pitch. Coot loved the craic and happily joined in the banter.However, he left the slagging to other less sensitive creatures of which there were plenty.A good example was the time I decided to get the footballers perm which was in vogue at the time. I should have known better.I got slaughtered, Dart declaring that I looked more like Shirley Temple than Kevin Keegan.Those were the days, as the saying goes, but happily there were plenty of good days ahead of us.We have had many reunions with Coot, an ever present and every one of them underlined the strength of the bond we enjoy so much.Sadly those reunions tend to be confined to wakes and funerals nowadays and the baby of our team has now joined Shane Breen, Paddy Galbraith and Marty Ross on the sidelines.Coot would have been the first to remind me that the Rec wasnrsquot only about the players.The one and only Charlie Oakes was highly influential in his role as assistant manager, while Austy Keating doubled as chairman and groundsman for many years.Joe Lyttle was our physio and his son Joea loyal player for years while my sister Tina was a committee member and a fanatical fan.They were all fully paid up members of the Rec family and we continue to mourn their loss.I would love to have name checked every single member of the Rec family in this piece but time and space didnrsquot allow. My apologies.The laughter which rang through Cootrsquos house during his wake was a fitting farewell for someone who loved to laugh.He was a very special human being. We will miss him forever. Rest in peace mate..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityWelsh Labourrsquos Jane Hutt was re-elected for the sixth Senedd earlier this month - she has held the seat since the Welsh Parliament first formed  years ago. She is the only MS to have served as a Minister in every Welsh Government to date.Ms Hutt ndash who was a South Glamorgan County councillor for  years before first obtaining her Senedd seat in  ndash said: ldquoIt was a lovely outcome ndash itrsquos humbling that people have put their trust in me and Irsquom very grateful.ldquoItrsquos an honour to serve people for the next five years. Therersquos so much to do and Irsquom hitting the ground running.MS Hutt has campaigned for equality for many years she became the first National Co-ordinator of Welsh Womenrsquos Aid in  and was a founder of South Glamorgan Womenrsquos Workshop.ldquoI want safety for all people ndash men and women, said Ms Hutt, who has recently had meetings with Vale of Glamorgan councillors and other agencies about how to make all areas safe for people.Ms Hutt had engaged with Vale of Glamorgan residents throughout her years as an MS, with the coronavirus pandemic and effects of lockdown a concern for the community over the last year,ldquoItrsquos a very dficult time for people, said Ms Hutt."Irsquove been fortunate to serve in First Minister Mark Drakefordrsquos cabinet... and his approach is based on team-work and evidence - not just medical or clinical, but social."Every step of the journey Irsquove focused on the impact [of Covid] on communities, including BAME communities and those with disabilities.ldquoDetrimental issues affecting the community and the people within it are at the fore-front, but I also work with police and the PCC. We have regular discussions about the impact of Covid, and lockdowns, and the easing of restrictions.ldquoIrsquove been engaging with police and Vale of Glamorgan Council enforcement officers to protect our communities and encourage respectful visits to our beautul coasts.     Ms Hutt is also supportive of business lsquoboth large and smallrsquo ndash and has also shown her support for Barry Hospital - in  she campaigned against a planned closure of the -bed Sam Davies Ward at Barry Hospital.ldquoBarry Hospital does wonderful work," said Ms Hutt.The Sam Davies ward played an important role in the Covid pandemic and will continue to do so.Ms Hutt also praised volunteers in the Vale of Glamorgan - and across Wales - for the tremendous support theyve shown within their communities. Earlier this year she thanked a number of volunteers, including Cowbridge Male Voice Choir, for their efforts throughout the coronavirus pandemic.Ms Hutt also engages with young people and supported The Schools CouncilsRegulations  which meant all schools in Wales need a council, enabling pupils to discuss matters relating to school, education, or other areas of concern, and to make representations on these to the governing body and the head teacher."This has helped pupils interest in being citizens and engaging with politics," said Ms Hutt.During the Senedd  election - for the first time - people aged  and  were given the option to vote."It was lovely to meet families who has discusses parties and their manestos," said Ms Hutt."Many of the young people I spoke to had made up their minds [about who to vote for]. Im glad young people felt empowered. Theyve been very much focused on the impact of the pandemic, but theyre also looking out for parents and grandparents generations in a caring way."To the young people who went to their polling stations [to vote] thank you for taking initiative - we will move Wales forward."People have put their trust in me and I will continue to serve all people across all areas of the Vale of Glamorgan." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. If you have an enclosed garden you might be getting in the way of their plans.One of the main reasons why hedgehogs are declining in Britain is because our fences and walls are becoming more and more secure, reducing the amount of land available to them.Penarth Hedgehog Street will help to connect gardens allowing hedgehogs more space to breed, find food and keep them off the roads. This will form part of the national Hedgehog Street campaign.The project street map for the Penarth estate taking part in the schemeAs part of the project, residents will be able to borrow footprint tracking tunnels and camera traps to monitor and record the presence of hedgehogs.Emily Shaw, the Local Nature Partnership Co-ordinator for the Vale of Glamorgan, said the mission is to reconnect people in the Vale with nature.MORE NEWS:ldquoThe way we will do this is by developing a nature recovery network with partners, where we hope to engage the public, local community groups and organisations, as well as schools and businesses to take part in practical action for nature in their communities, she added.ldquoThe Valersquos LNP is one of several across Wales with each county hosting their own LNP and is part of a fantastic network through a project called LNP Cymru which is co-ordinated by the WCVA and funded by the Welsh Government.As part of Hedgehog Awareness Week, the Vale Local Nature Partnership has launched a new pilot hedgehog highways scheme on a residential estate in Penarth to encourage residents to create small holes in their fences to help hedgehogs move around more easily. title: penarth ramblers explore history nature walk
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt was girl power when ten female walkers joined Joy and sheepdog Bracken from Penarth and District Ramblers at Penarth clftop for an . mile walk, with no stiles only gates and which would see them experiencing the weather of all four seasons in one day. They set off on a socially distanced walk in lovely spring sunshine across the old pitch and putt course before joining part of the old railway line, now a walk and cycle way, and heading through a built up area Lavernock Road led them into Cosmeston Country Park.Past the eastern lake with its floating jetty where canoes can be safely launched and making their way through the eastern paddock with its carpet of pretty cowslips, open meadows led them towards Old Cogan Hall Farm, where they deviated into the churchyard of St Peterrsquos for morning break in glorious warm sunshine reminiscent of summer. Admiring the herring bone masonry which dates to Celtic and Saxon times and the ancient yew trees that could even pre-date this lovely old church, which allegedly is the oldest building in Penarth and hearing some of its long and interesting history, it fell into disrepair in the th century. By the th century the ruinous building was a cattle shelter until the latter part of the rsquos when the rd Marquis of Bute was persuaded to pay for its renovation.Mile Road built by the Bute family led them to the western paddock and through the sun-dappled Cogan Wood to re-enter fields where a footbridge led them across the Sully Brook for the short climb up to Home Farm, with its glorious views towards the eastern end of Barry and the surrounding farmland. Exiting through a gate, some road walking in a southerly direction brought them into Sully village and pounding pavements to reach the Jubilee Hall and the cricket field, the full beauty of Sully Bay with its views across the Bristol Channel towards the Somerset coastline and Hayes Point to the west confronted them.     With the wind beginning to pick up they tramped by track and field to the public slipway at Sully beach and stopped for lunch utilising rocks for seating whilst gazing eastwards towards Sully Island and Flat and Steep Holm beyond, as clouds thickened overhead and the temperature dropped making it feel more like autumn.Time to move on along part of the long distance Wales Coast Path, through the playing fields to exit onto Beach Road, following it to the car park of the Captainrsquos We where there were only a few people sitting at outdoor tables for food and drink, not really enjoyable in the cool breeze.The fairly quiet St Maryrsquos Well Bay Road brought them up past The Bay Caravan Park and into fields with growing crops where, without any warning a sudden short sharp shower of rain engulfed the group forcing coats to be swtly donned.Crossing a wooden footbridge into the delightful Lavernock Nature Reserve the grassy path led them into the remains of the WW gun emplacements. Initially in the late rsquos the original Lavernock Gun Battery was built to protect the Bristol and Cardf shipyards and the Bristol Channel, but unfortunately most of the original buildings now lie underneath the caravan park.Being bombarded by a short hail storm whilst moving on through the nature reserve, lovingly cared for by volunteers and passing the man-made pond with its surrounding carpet of bluish violet bugle, a plant which attracts moths, butterflies and bees, before exiting onto Fort Road their route led them past the Marconi Holiday Village and the Church of St Lawrence before heading along the clftop. With thick black clouds heading up the English side of the Bristol Channel, the race was on to get back before the rain hit. As the weather turned wintry and the wind increased, a huge shower of hailstones and heavy rain struck them on the open Penarth clftop soaking them as they made their way back to their start point.You can follow the grouprsquos exploits before, during and after lockdown on Facebook. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySt Richard GwynCatholic High School, on Argae Lane in Barry, has  pupils currently on roll, with this number increasing to  - the schoolrsquos biggest Year Seven cohort yet.Mr David Blackwell has been head teacher at the school since February , following his role as deputy head for more than four years.Headteacher Mr David BlackwellHe is backed by deputy head Matthew Dunn assistant headteachers Laura Burnettand Amy Leftleyand senior core leader Sharon Macleod.The schoolrsquos last Estyn report was in  ndash the school was rated lsquoadequatersquo overall but with good prospects of improvement.Explaining some of the improvements made since, Mr Blackwell said: ldquoWe have fully embedded the Jesuit Pupil Profile into the le of staff and students."The Jesuit Pupil Profile gives a focus to the citizens that we wish to nurture at SRG. It reminds staff and students that virtues towards the needs of others is paramount to the essence of our humanity."He continued: We have always prioritised wellbeing of our students but over the last two years we have developed a lsquowellbeing progress centre. Support staff have been trained extensively to ensure that all students are ready to learn.ldquoThe wellbeing team are always on hand to assist with the students wellbeing by offering sessions for ELSA, Thrive and Mental Health Wellbeing. We even have two wellbeing dogs that support some of our more vulnerable learners.ldquoWe work very closely with a iety of external agencies to support our students needs to ensure students are engaged and feel safe and secure and able to fulfil their full potential.The school caters to pupils with additional learning needs and to staff wellbeing. Staff at the school have training, progression opportunities, open door policy of support, and clear lines of communication.     ldquoTeaching and learning continues to be our core focus, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoThe  Inspection report praised students at SRG for lsquotheir positive attitude to learningrsquo. We have built upon this and we now offer a Scholarrsquos Programme to prepare students for their education pathway.ldquoWe want to offer students a chance to broaden their educational experience with us. We have broadened our option subjects at KS - we are now able to offer Construction, Health and Social Care and Textiles and Fashion.ldquoWe are committed to the promotion of SRG as a learning organisation. To this end we have entered into an ITE Partnership with Cardf politan University and an alliance with St.Illtydrsquos Catholic Comprehensive in Cardf. It is mutually beneficial since we help develop new teachers into the profession and we are able to utilise educational research to improve standards across both key stages.The Catholic school strives to ensures pupils succeed, while also being good people.ldquoWe aim for our pupils to live by the ethos of our pupil profile which is about virtues to empower them to be a success in le, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe are the faith secondary school of the Vale and so provide an excellent secondary education that runs equally alongside our holistic development of our pupils as iniduals and good all round people.The Catholic ethos is embedded into daily le at the school, with morning prayer, virtues-based assemblies, and daily reflection.ldquoAll staff engage in role modelling behaviour that reflects the Catholic virtues of honesty, integrity and forgiveness, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoDuring normal school times Mass is a frequent part of our school le ndash not all pupils come to us with a faith background, but they all appreciate the values that we try to weave into our everyday lives.Along with the schoolrsquos ethical focus St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School has an abundance of extra-curricular activities on offer, including school trips.Sporty youngsters can take part in football, rugby, netball, hockey, tennis, badminton, athletics, cheerleading and street dance. Therersquos also Clwb Cymraeg and an array of creative activities on offer ndash including art club, textiles club, choir, SRG band.Bi-annually the music, drama, and art departments join forces to produce and perform an arts production.St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School strives to form lsquopositive relationshipsrsquo with families and the local community and has a Facebook group regularly updated with video messages from Mr Blackwell and key messages for families.Each year group has a Progress Leader who is a point of contact for families as well as our Wellbeing and Progress Centre who liaises with families on a regular basis. Plus, St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School is in the process of obtaining the Investors in Families , which ndash in a nutshell ndash lsquois a quality mark that recognises the work that schools and other settings undertake with families to improve outcomes for children and young people.rsquoThe school is also lsquoproudrsquo to have worked with numerous charities ndash including fundraising for local food banks and helping Keep Wales Tidy with beach cleans.The school has also adapted a lsquogreatrsquo deal during the coronavirus pandemic ndash with the immediate priority being health and safety such as year group lsquobubblesrsquo, separate lunches, allocated outdoor spaces, regular sanitizing and face coverings.ldquoThe biggest impact, in terms of day to day operation, meant teachers moved more between lessons than students, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoCrucial to adapting to the pandemic was to adoption of online learning. There have been periods of lockdown with no pupils in school as well as fortnightly periods that have required year groups to isolate.He praised the training and use of online s as lsquotransformativersquo. and added that - while itrsquos lsquofantasticrsquo to resume in-person learning these changes and developments will continue to improve how the school operates.The school is lsquovery fortunatersquo to have been supported by the local authority to make the best of the buildings they have, but the school is awaiting progress on a new build under the st Century schools programme, financed by Welsh Government.ldquoWe firmly believe that what goes on inside school is more important than the way the building looks externally, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe have amazing staff who work exceptionally hard to make the best of the facilities we have, all pupils who come to us get a great educational experience.ldquoHowever, we are still awaiting progress on a new build. It was used for dances during the second world war, and a nightclub in the s and s. The building fell into disrepair about a decade ago, but a charity called Penarth Arts and Craft Limited spent lottery funding on renovation.Then the pavilion reopened in  as an arts and culture venue with a cinema, exhibition space, meeting rooms and a cafe. However, the charity later struggled with directors leaving and challenging trading conditions, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic.MORE NEWS:Towards the end of last year, the charity entered discussions with the Vale council and the National Lottery about what could be done. The council then took over control of the building last February, and asked the public for suggestions about how the pavilion should be used.A new cafe has opened in the pavilion, run by the councilrsquos armrsquosBig Fresh Catering Company. All profits from this company are put into providing healthy meals for schools.Essential repairs and maintenance have also been carried out on the building, including replacing the air conditioning repairing the lighting, fire doors, and gas boilers and testing the lt, water hygiene, and fire alarms. Initial works have cost about pound,.     The kitchen has also seen repairs and cleaning outside walls have been cleaned and the decking jet washed tables have been sanded and resealed and a broken window was replaced. Public wi has been improved and the cinema projector has been maintained.The childrenrsquos section of Penarth Library will temporarily be relocated to the pavilion. The section is currently not well ventilated enough to be Covid-secure, but it should be in the pavilion. Regular activities like Story Time will be held at the pavilion.The building could also soon host live music and a bar, as the council is applying for licences to play music and serve alcohol there.More than , people responded to a public consultation on what should happen next with the building from March  until April . Most would like to see included in the plans a cinema, cafe, bar or street food space also with live music, theatre and comedy shows.Some respondents suggested the pavilion could run similar to Chapter Arts in Cardf. Council bosses are now drawing up a business plan which should include firmer details on what will happen next to the building. The upper with decked sun terrace and raised border with steps falling to a lower lawn.The rear of the property accommodates a substantial patio with sunny south westerly aspect and arched gateway which leads to a garden room.This property is on the market with Burnett Davies with Easton, Vale of Glamorgan.
