title: hundreds call new health centre built llantwit major
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMore than  local people are urging the Cardf and Vale University Health Boardto build a health centre on Eagleswell Road, where a former primary school closed in .The disused plot of land is currently owned by Vale of Glamorgan council, and is allocated for  potential houses in the local development plan.But campaigners want the council to allow the health board to build a new health centre there, complaining the townrsquos current surgeries arenrsquot up to scratch.Councillor Gwyn John, of the Llantwit First Independent party, is organising the petition. He raised concerns that the hundreds of new houses in and around Llantwit Major arenrsquot seeing the increased investment in local public services needed to cater for the growing population.He said: ldquoThere are more and more houses in the town. Therersquos hardly any green space left and our services are really struggling.Two doctors surgeries currently cater for the town: Coastal Vale and Western Vale. Cllr John claimed Coastal Vale is ldquoat capacity and the Western Vale building is ldquoover  years old.He said: ldquoThe actual building needs replacing, itrsquos not in a great condition. It needs replacing and modernising.Cardf and Vale UHB is drawing up plans for major changes on how clinical services are delivered. This will likely see three lsquohealth and wellbeing centresrsquo with services like x-rays, out-of-hours GPs, community mental health teams, and ambulatory care.MORE NEWS:The health board is also planning nine lsquowellbeing hubsrsquo, either developing existing places like health centres, leisure centres or libraries or in new buildings such as Maelfa in Cardf. These wellbeing hubs will include GP services, midwery, and primary mental health care.     The idea is to move clinical services away from large hospitals like the University Hospital of Wales, at the Heath in Cardf, avoiding the need for people to travel long distances for care.Cllr John supports this move but says residents in the western part of the Vale of Glamorgan are currently undeserved with health services mdash and with the hundreds of new houses being built in the area, Llantwit would be ideal for a new health centre.He is hoping to get many more signatures for his petition to build the new health centre in Llantwit Major, with a table set up on the precinct in the town on Saturday, for residents who arenrsquot on the internet or havenrsquot seen the campaign online yet.He said: ldquoItrsquos all very well building homes, thatrsquos fine. But we have to have the infrastructure.The health board said any investment in new health and wellbeing centres or wellbeing hubs is some time away.A Cardf and Vale UHB spokesperson said: ldquoThe intention is for a wellbeing hub to be placed in the western Vale, but this may be some years away as part of our overall plan. In terms of where the site will be based, this will be subject to an engagement process.ldquoThere will be a health and wellbeing centre in the Vale work will be commencing in terms of engagement in relation to this within the next few months.A Vale of Glamorgan council spokesperson said: ldquoAny need for a new medical centre would be a matter for the Cardf and Vale University Health Board.ldquoNo planning application for such a building has been submitted and currently the land in question has been allocated as a signicant strategic development site for the councilrsquos house building programme. title: research shows urgent issues facing cardiff south penarth residents
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt comes as the UK Government is set to outline its plan to level up the country, though anti-poverty charity the Joseph Rowntree Foundation said it must improve on its "piecemeal" attempts so far.A survey by the think tank Demos asked , adults in parliamentary constituencies across Great Britain to choose which one of nine issues most urgently needs improving in their local area.In Cardf South and Penarth, .#% of residents chose good local shops.This was followed by good transport services , and housing that suits their needs .Mel Grfin, owner of Grfin Books, said she was ldquosurprised at these figures.ldquoIn Penarth I think wersquore very fortunate to have a wide range of excellent independent shops as well as a good representation of national chains, she added.ldquoYou can get pretty much anything you need in the town itself without the need to travel into Cardf. Despite the challenges of the past year, wersquove all hung in there, and I believe there are currently no empty shops in the town centre which is a great indicator for the future.Angelina Hall of Penarth Business Group added: ldquoIf we offer a good mix of hospitality, retail and services, we will ensure our High Street can prosper, attracting both locals and visitors.MORE NEWS:"Whilst City Centres have seen punishing closures leaving huge gaps in their offering, Penarth businesses have worked hard to ersy and adapt in a challenging economic climate.The most pressing issue across Britain was also shops, followed by good transport and jobs.Demos said prioritising retailers was particularly prevalent in more built-up areas, while rural communities were more likely to see a lack of quality transport as a problem.     The think-tank has urged the Government to reflect on its research as it considers how best to spend the pound. billion earmarked for a levelling-up fund to reduce inequality across the UK.In Cardf South and Penarth, an estimated % of residents think that the provision of facilities they consider most important is nearer to bad than good ndash compared to the national average of %.The Centre for Cities said the main challenge facing many urban areas is the comparatively low education levels among the workforce, meaning well-paid jobs are scarce and wages lower.A Skills and Post- Education Bill ndash new legislation aimed at reforming education for older teenagers and adults ndash was also announced in the Queens Speech.But the Centre for Cities said the Government must "make good on its promises" to improve education and training opportunitiesit is to level up less prosperous parts of the country.Andrew Carter, the think tanks chief executive, said: "Lower wages mean less disposable income to spend in local shops and other amenities. As a result many struggle and close ndash creating a general feeling of being left behind."The Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government said the Levelling Up Fund will regenerate high streets, upgrade local transport and invest in cultural assets.A spokeswoman added: ldquoOur Plan for Jobs will create opportunities for people of all ages wherever they live by boosting skills and giving them the best possible chance of getting a job." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: rnli launch campaign due increase visitors summer
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityWith uncertainty over foreign holidays and international travel, the RNLI is predicting this summer will be the busiest ever on the Welsh coast, as Covid restrictions are eased and people choose to lsquostaycationrsquo.The lesaving charity and HM Coastguard are launching the safety campaign ahead of the Bank Holiday weekend and half-term holidays, urges people to choose leguarded beaches when they visit the coast.The charity has also teamed up with experts at Bangor University to collaborate and explore the best ways to keep people safe.This weekend leguards in Wales willto their posts at Rhyl and Prestatyn in Denbighshire, Rest Bay in Bridgend, Pembrey in Carmarthenshire, Newgale Central in Pembrokeshire.In Ceredigion, RNLI leguards are currently providing a service at weekends at Llangrannog and at Borth, this will become a regular daily service from the half term holiday running until September. Leguards will also provide cover over the school holidays at Aberystwyth South, Tresaith and Aberporth.In a survey,commissioned by the RNLI, % of those questioned - aged - - expect to visit a UK beach or the coast between April and September, with around half of that number likely to do so three or more times.A signicantly higher proportion of the publicalso said they plan to visit the coast more than usual this year, compared to  .Chris Cousens, RNLI Water Safety Lead in Wales says:"We are expecting this summer to be the busiest ever for our leguards and volunteer leboat crews in Wales and the survey figures back that up. With its stunning scenery and spectacular beaches, we are certain people will flock to the Welsh coastline and want people to enjoy it."We do however urge everyone to respect the water, think about their own safety and know what to do in an emergency.     "Our main advice is to visit a leguarded beach and swim between the red and yellow flags."RNLI leguards will be patrolling around  beaches this summer to offer advice on how to stay safe and they are also there to help anyone who gets into trouble."Whether yoursquore at a leguarded beach or not, look out for safety signage and seek advice on safe places to swim, keep your children under supervision at all times, avoid swimming alone where possible and know to alert the leguards or call  or  and ask for Coastguard in an emergency."Coastal areas provide a great opportunity to enjoy fresh air and open space but they can be an unpredictable environment, particularly during early summer when air temperatures start warming up but water temperatures remain very cold, increasing the risk of cold water shock."The key summer safety advice is:Visit a leguarded beach  swim between the red and yellow flagsIf you get into trouble Float to Live ndash lie on your back and relax, resisting the urge to thrash aboutCall  or  in an emergency and ask for the CoastguardNot everyone who finds themselves in trouble in the water, expected to even get wet. RNLI statistics for Wales show people enjoying a walk and getting cut off by the tide caused almost  per centof all RNLI leboat launches over the last decade - more than double the UK average.Leguards rescue hundreds more stranded people every year.For this reason the RNLI has teamed up with experts at Bangor University to gain a better understanding of peoplersquos understanding of tides and the associated risks at the coast.As part of a long-term project, the lesaving charity and leading Welsh university will shortly launch a survey to gain a better understanding of peoplersquos knowledge to be able to effectively explore the appropriate interventions.With bigger than usual tides this Bank Holiday weekend, the RNLI is hopeful people will take heed of specialist advice.For further information on the beach safety campaign visit: RNLI.org BeachUK.A full list of RNLI leguarded beaches can be found here: rnli.org find-my-nearest leguarded-beaches. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: bethan roper inquest jury hears friends

These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityBethan Roper, , suffered fatal head injuries while a passenger on the Great Western Railwaytravelling at around mph.Miss Roper, of Penarth, was ing home to South Wales from a day out with friends Christmas shopping in Bath.Avon Coronerrsquos Court heard Miss Roper and her three friends, Elizabeth Winstone Evans, Chanelle Hagland and Madeleine Owens, had boarded the train at Bath Spa station on the evening of December , .The GWR London Paddington to Exeter service was using carriages fitted with droplight windows to enable passengers to use the handle on the outside when they needed to leave the train at the .Investigators told the inquest that the warning label above the window, a yellow sticker with the words: lsquoCaution do not lean out of window when train is movingrsquo, was not a sufficient deterrent.Miss Roper was fatally injured just a few minutes after the train left Bath when her head was struck by an ash tree branch growing on land adjacent to the line.PC Kate Aldred, of British Transport Police, spoke with Miss Hagland when the train arrived at Bristol Temple Meads station shortly after the incident and made written notes of the conversation.ldquoThe train had been travelling five or six minutes when Miss Evans opened the pulldown window of the door, Pc Aldred said.ldquoMiss Evans leant her head out of the window very slightly for about  seconds and then said something like, lsquoGirls try thisrsquo.ldquoMiss Evans put her head back inside the carriage and then Miss Roper has immediately stepped forward and put her head right out of the window.ldquoMiss Hagland was sat on the floor close to Miss Roperrsquos legs.ldquoMiss Roperrsquos head must only have been out for five seconds when Miss Hagland heard the sound of an impact.ldquoMiss Roper fell backwards towards Miss Hagland and caught Miss Roper.     ldquoMiss Roper then fell forwards and slumped onto the floor.Later, Miss Hagland told police in a statement that by the time they caught the train they were not ldquodrunk or disorderly.ldquoWersquove all had a quite a few drinks but we are used to drinking like that.ldquoWe had all sobered up by then and drunk ourselves sober, she told officers.Describing the minutes before the incident, Miss Hagland said they were all in the vestibule area of the train as it was busy and her friend Miss Evans pulled down the window of the door as she was hot.ldquoLizzy leant her head out of the window just slightly and her hair was blowing, Miss Hagland said.ldquoI think Lizzy was hot and I didnrsquot even know those windows go down.ldquoI heard Lizzy say, lsquolook at this girlsrsquo and when she pulled in Beth charged over and did exactly the same thing and she put her head out just a little bit more than Lizzy did.ldquoFrom what I can remember the shoulders were still in the carriage.ldquoI was just about to stand up when the branch hit her head.ldquoIt was pretty much straight awayhellip five seconds.ldquoShe kind of took two steps back and stumbled and fell right into me and fell forward.A post-mortem examination found Miss Roper had died from head injuries.Toxicology tests found she had a blood alcohol level of mg in ml of blood, meaning she was nearly twice the drink drive limit.Miss Roper worked for the Welsh Refugee Council charity and was chairwoman of Young Socialists Cardf.The hearing continues. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url title: twickenham turned walk in vaccine centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityUp to , first dose jabs are being made available for those in the local area who have not yet been vaccinated.The event ndash called Letrsquos Tackle Covid ndash aims to increase the number of vaccinations as cases of the Indian coronavirus iant surge in Hounslow, west London.A spokesman for Twickenham Stadium said it was ldquoproud the venue would be supporting one of ldquothe biggest walk-in vaccination events in England.At the moment people who are aged over  are being called up for a vaccination in England.Anyone who is eligible for their first dose can walk in without an appointment but by .pm event organisers said that anyone over  would be able to get an injection as they did not want any of the vaccine to be wasted.Scotland international rugby union player Rory Hutchinson was among those who got a vaccination at Twickenham Stadium. vw,vw,px, px"People queue to receive a coronavirus vaccination at Twickenham The -year-old Northampton Saints player told the PA news agency ldquofor me it is the right thing to do and that is why I am here today.He said: ldquoIt was a really smooth process. I thought they were very professional. It was easy to find. I walked straight in and got my vaccine done. Then just had to wait a short while to make sure I was OK.ldquoI think we have been through a really tough time recently and hopefully we are on the mend now. I am just doing what I can to support that.Student and sports fan Flo Flake-Parsons said it was ldquoquite exciting to get her jab in a place ldquowhere there has been so many happy memories.The -year-old of Chiswick, west London, said there were no queues by the time she got her afternoon injection.Saying it was ldquoquite a relief to the get the vaccination, she added: ldquoIt has been a really rubbish time for everyone and this is a good step back towards normality.     Dr Genevieve Small, who is a Harrow GP and the clinical lead for the north west London vaccination programme, described the Twickenham event which had been organised in a short space of time as a service which had been ldquosomething quite powerful for a range of people.She said: ldquoWe have been able to provide this facility on the day for people who perhaps knew they were allowed to get the vaccine but had not come around to sorting it out, or who have just been more spontaneous, or who had previously questions about the programme and now feel ready to come forward for the vaccination.ldquoThere is, of course, a wantto make sure we are protecting the areas that are seeing more cases of the new iant.ldquoWe have been given the opportunity . We have been given the vaccine and we have gone for it.Over  vaccinators, which includes a mixture of GPs and nurses, were on duty to hand out the jabs.Thousands of people had queued up around the rugby pitch as the doors opened in order to make their way into the stadium concourse which had been turned into a vaccination hub. vw,vw,px, px"Anti-vaccination protesters demonstrated outside Pippa Nightingale, the chief nurse for north-west London, encouraged people ldquoto take some time out of your day and come and see us during the fine bank holiday weather.Kelly OrsquoNeill, Hounslow Councilrsquos director of public health, said: ldquoGetting the vaccine is the single most important step we can take to protect ourselves, our families and our communities against Covid- and we encourage all our local community to have their vaccine as soon as they are eligible.Twickenham Stadium venue director Mark Lynch said: ldquoWe are proud to have supported the NHS for over a year during the pandemic, first with a test centre in Twickenham Stadium car park and now to set up this mass vaccination facility in record time.ldquoItrsquos taken less than a week to turn around and Irsquod like to thank all  stadium and NHS employees involved for their hard work to make this happen.ldquoLike rugby clubs across the country, we feel itrsquos important for us to do our bit to support our local communities.The event has been organised by the local NHS trust in partnership with Hounslow Council and supported by Englandrsquos Rugby Football Union ..push,i[r].l*new title: blockbuster movies ready for omniplex reopening
story: Traffic Attendants back on streets next week   Toddler, who died in tragic incident, is named locallyNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleBlockbuster movies ready for Omniplex reopeningMovie buffs will be delighted that the local Omniplex chain is all set to reopen to the public next Monday - pending the easing of Lockdown restrictions.By Carmel RobinsonMonday, th May , : pm  "       "  Ready to roll out the reels, the Omniplex Cinemas are awaiting official confirmation from the NI Executive - which is due on Thursday .The cinema chain plans to begin its phased reopening of five sites, with Omniplex Craigavon Lisburn, Dundonald, Newry and Bangor welcoming customers back to a covid safe way from this date. Eight more Omniplex locations across the country are ready to resume screening from Friday th May marking the first time this year for avid movie goers to enjoy the big screen experience. ]]Craigavon Omniplex.The cinema chain – the largest in NI, closed all of its venues on December , , when all areas of the UK and Ireland were under pandemic restrictions. Paul John Anderson, Director of Omniplex Cinemas said: “We are thrilled to finally be welcoming back cinema goers for the first time this year. We strongly believe in the power of escapism that a couple of hours spent at the cinema provides and we are looking forward to opening our doors for the ultimate big screen experience. We have worked hard over the last year to ensure our customers can enjoy the magic of cinema once again. We continue to follow public health advice and the safety of our team and customers remains of utmost importance.” Safety measures will include limited capacity m distance between parties for social distancing requirements face coverings to be worn by staff and audiences when moving within cinema buildings and staggered showtimes to name a few. Omniplex Cinemas will also be operating enhanced online booking to make the visit as contactless as possible with increased cleaning regimes and hand sanitising stations in every foyer. Visitors will be expected to wear face masks but will be allowed to remove them when seated in auditoriums for eating or drinking. Paul added: “It’s been a long and dficult year for us all with restrictions affecting our daily lives. We know that our audiences are eager to get back to the big screen and we cannot wait to see people experiencing the cinema once again.” Several film studios had paused the release of their ‘tentpole’ blockbusters in , opting for release dates in the latter half of . From th May, film fans can enjoy films including Peter Rabbit , voiced by stars including James Corden and Margot Robbie and much-anticipated horror film The Conjuring . A raft of blockbuster films is set to be released in this summer with Marvel releasing the much-delayed Black Widow on th July. DC Comics will play to a similar field of movie goers with the release of The Suicide Squad on th August. The ninth instalment of Fast and Furious will come to cinema screens across NI on th July this year. The th James Bond will also grace the movie screens with No Time to Die featuring Daniel Craig as  expected to come out on th September in the UK and Ireland. Tickets are on sale now in advance of these reopening dates at www.omniplex.ie. The remaining sites in Derry, Belfast, Antrim, Carrickfergus, Omagh, Downpatrick, Banbridge and Dungannon will open again from Friday th May. Omniplex is the largest cinema chain in Ireland, with over  screens in  locations.
